</style>

column1: 1. De student is vertrouwd met de notie  van een afleidingssysteem en de gerelateerde eigenschappen van betrouwbaarheid en volledigheid. De student is op de hoogte van het bestaan van diverse afleidingssystemen voor de propositie logica en kan de belangrijkste verschillen tussen deze systemen benoemen.
2. De student is in staat om het tableau (afleidings-) systeem  te gebruiken om na te gaan of een argument (on)geldig is en, indien een argument ongeldig is, een tegenvoorbeeld te construeren.

3. De student is bekend met Quine’s drieledige onderscheid tussen veridical paradoxen, falsidical paradoxen en antinomieën. De student kent enkele centrale antinomieën en kan uitleggen hoe deze een niet-klassieke logica kunnen motiveren.
4. De student kent de  basisbeginselen van, en motivatie voor, enkele niet- klassieke, met name meerwaardige, logica’s.
5.  De student kan standpunten formuleren en onderbouwen betreffende epistemische en epistemologische onderwerpen
6. De student kan zelf voorbeelden en tegenvoorbeelden bedenken en uitwerken en in relatie brengen tot klassieke, epistemische en epistemologische denkbeelden en teksten.
7. De student kan de belangrijkste auteurs, begrippen, distincties, en theorieën uit de epistemologie identificeren, omschrijven, vergelijken en toepassen.

column1: De cursus omvat twee luiken die op elkaar afgestemd worden: een logisch luik en een systematisch luik.

In het logische luik bestuderen we de predicatenlogica. We beschouwen dan ook redeneringen waarvan de correctheid niet alleen steunt op de betekenis van de voegtekens maar ook op de betekenis van de kwantoren “voor alle"" en “er is minstens één"". We onderscheiden het semantische begrip “geldig gevolg van” en het syntactische begrip “afleidbaar uit” en bestuderen de relatie tussen deze twee begrippen.

In het systematische luik worden de centrale problemen uit formele ontologie en de analytische metafysica aan de orde gesteld: universalia, substanties, tijd, compositie, persistentie, causaliteit, responsafhankelijkheid en wereldbeelden.

Studenten mogen één werkcollege missen. Indien ze meerdere werkcolleges missen, moeten er ter compensatie opgaven gemaakt worden die bij het (de) gemiste werkcollege(s) horen en welke beoordeeld worden. Het tentamenonderdeel dat overeenkomt met de gemiste werkcolleges zal beoordeeld worden met het laagste cijfer behaald voor (i) de compenserende opgaven (ii) de tentamenopgaven behorende bij de gemiste werkcolleges.

column1: 1.. De student is vertrouwd met de formele taal van de predicaten logica (welke naast de logische voegtekens de kwantoren “voor alle"" en “er is minstens één bevat), bekend met de (beperkte) uitdrukkingskracht van deze formele taal en in staat om alledaagse deductieve argumenten te vertalen naar de taal van de predicaten logica.

2. De student is vertrouwd met Tarski’s waarheidsdefinitie voor de taal van de predicaten logica en gerelateerde noties zoals model, vervulbaarheid, vrije en gebonden variabele en in staat om, gebruik makend van deze noties, (alledaagse) argumenten op hun geldigheid te beoordelen.

3.  De student is vertrouwd met een tableau (afleidings-) systeem voor de predicatenlogica en in staat om dit systeem  te gebruiken om na te gaan of een argument (on)geldig is en, indien een argument ongeldig is, een tegenvoorbeeld te construeren.

4. De student is vertrouwd met enkele toepassingen van (het modelbegrip uit) de predicaten logica in de analytische filosofie, met name in de analytische metafysica, en in staat om zich hier kritisch tot te verhouden.
5. De student kan standpunten formuleren en onderbouwen betreffende ontische, ontologische en metafysische onderwerpen

6. De student kan zelf aspecten van wereldbeelden ontrafelen, uitwerken, in relatie brengen tot klassieke, ontische, ontologische en metafysische denkbeelden en teksten, en er zich kritisch toe verhouden
7. De student kan de belangrijkste auteurs, begrippen, distincties, en theorieën uit de metafysica identificeren, omschrijven, vergelijken en toepassen.</body>

column1: Het proces van Medische Anamnese, Lichamelijk Onderzoek, Klinisch Redeneren en Gespreksvaardigheden en Reflectie heet Consultvoering (CV). Het CV-onderwijs loopt als een rode draad door de bachelor Geneeskunde heen. In het eerste bachelorjaar (Ba1) ligt het accent op het aanleren van een anamnese en de grondbeginselen van het klinisch redeneren. In jaar 2 wordt dit verder uitgebouwd en komt hier het aanleren van verrichten van lichamelijk onderzoek bij met alle bijbehorende handelingen voor veilig en hygiënisch werken. In jaar 3 worden anamnese en lichamelijk onderzoek geïntegreerd in een volledig consult.
1.      hoe je een anamnese kunt afnemen (gesprekstechnieken, structuur anamnese);
2.      de (bio)medische kennis uit de thema’s toe te passen in (gesimuleerde) patiëntcasuïstiek om de oorzaak van het aangereikte patiëntprobleem te achterhalen;
3.      hoe je met (simulatie)patiënten en collegae omgaat (attitude en professioneel gedrag);
4.      na te denken over welke invloed je eigen persoon(lijkheid) heeft bij het functioneren als aanstaand arts (reflectie).
De beoordeling van het CV onderwijs bestaat uit:
1.      aanwezigheid, voorbereiding en actieve en professionele deelname;
2.      een reflectieverslag: reflectie op je vaardigheden consultvoering;
3.      een vaardigheidstoets: voeren van een anamnese;
4.      een schriftelijke toets: de integratietoets waar je vermogen tot klinisch redeneren wordt getoetst.

column1: Deelname aan de VO-bijeenkomsten van de lijn Consultvoering is verplicht. Er geldt een aanwezigheidsplicht van 100%. De aanwezigheid bij de lessen wordt geregistreerd. Het onderwijs volg je in de groep waarin je bent ingedeeld. Wisselen van groep is niet mogelijk. Een bijeenkomst kan eventueel worden ingehaald (zie het algemene deel van de studentenhandleiding voor de procedure en voorwaarden). Voor de voorwaarden om aan de vaardigheidstoets (CV17) mee te doen én om de EC voor dit onderwijs te verkrijgen zie de paragraaf over toetsing in het algemene deel van de studentenhandleiding én de OER (https://www.erasmusmc.nl/geneeskunde/bachelor/regels-richtlijnen-handleidingen/OER/ ).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Instead of an elective a so-called business project can be carried out. This business project will be shorter than a regular internship. The advantage is that such a project can be carried out during one of the three elective blocks. A student can come up with a business project at a company of his or her choice or can select a project from a list that this master program aims at offering in cooperation with renowned innovative companies as Philips, Unilever, SHELL, ASML, Friesland-Campina, Rabo Bank, ING and other companies. The business project will be assessed separately from the thesis itself and should contain another focus than the thesis. The project is selected after consultation with the thesis coach.

Before the choice is made for electives and a business project, a manual will be available in which it is described in detail on what grounds the business project will be assessed. Part of the assessment criteria will be about how the student did his or her work within the company.
THIS ELECTIVE COUNTS AS A FREE ELECTIVE FOR MI STUDENTS ONLY. IN OTHER WORDS: in order to graduate you MUST complete at least two MI programme electives!

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In addition to the regular thesis work, the research project aims at acquiring more practical skills. Although such skills may differ among projects, in general the following skills may apply in the context of the company for which the project is carried out: Communication skills, teamwork skills, ability to adjust to company culture, ability to carry out a practical project under the supervision of a company manager.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In het vak maatschappelijke problemen en bestuurlijke oplossingen maken de studenten kennis met de wereld van de maatschappelijke problemen, het openbaar bestuur en de bestuurskunde. Ze leren in essentie wat het openbaar bestuur is, op welke wijze het openbaar bestuur tracht maatschappelijke problemen op te lossen en wat de rol van het vakgebied van de bestuurskunde hierbij is. Daarbij wordt specifiek ingegaan op de organisatie van het openbaar bestuur en de processen die daarin een rol spelen. De centrale vraag daarbij is welke principes van bestuurlijke vormgeving ten grondslag liggen aan de organisatie van het openbaar bestuur en welke spanningen daarbij kunnen optreden. Deze kennis vormt het basale vertrekpunt voor de verdere opleiding.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Na afloop van deze module kan de student:

column5: Maatschappelijke problemen herkennen en karakteriseren als beleidsproblemen;
Beargumenteren waarom er een openbaar bestuur is, wat haar democratische grondslag is, en wat haar belangrijkste functies zijn;
De organisatie en het functioneren van de rijksoverheid, provincies en gemeenten in Nederland beschrijven;
De organisatie en het functioneren van de Europese Unie en de Europese instellingen beschrijven;
Beargumenteren op welke wijze checks en balances in de formele bestuurlijke instituties zijn georganiseerd.
Beredeneren in welke mate de traditionele bestuurlijke instituties aansluiten bij de hedendaagse maatschappelijke vraagstukken;
Beschrijven wat het vakgebied van de bestuurskunde inhoudt en hoe dit vakgebied zich heeft ontwikkeld.

column2: </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85502,2019,Maatschappij en Beleid,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. A Molenveld', 'dr. W Belabas', 'JHB van der Veer, MSc', 'prof.dr. PWA Scholten']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: In deze module wordt 'beleid' benaderd vanuit het perspectief van de maatschappij. Niet het perspectief van de overheid wordt dus als vertrekpunt gekozen voor de beschouwing van beleid, maar juist de rol die verschillende coördinatiemechanismen kunnen vervullen in de productie van bepaalde publieke voorzieningen. Daarbij wordt getracht het concept ‘publicness’ op verschillende manieren in te vullen: vanuit de staat, de markt en de gemeenschap. Dit past ook bij de idee dat dat het probleemoplossende vermogen van een samenleving niet alleen wordt bepaald door de aanwezigheid van een overheid of staat die sturingskracht ontwikkelt. Het probleemoplossend vermogen van een samenleving heeft ook te maken met de mate waarin een samenleving over voldoende veerkracht en zelforganiserend vermogen beschikt (of via de markt of via allerlei gemeenschappen), en waarbij de staat of de overheid een andere rol inneemt; een rol die veel eerder coproducerend is dan producerend is. Dit heeft ook gevolgen voor de wijze waarop beleid wordt ontwikkeld en uitgevoerd en hoe beleid, dan kan worden geconceptualiseerd.</body>

<title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Macroeconomics is the study of the structure and working of an economy as a whole, rather than of individual markets. It defines the main variables in the aggregate economy (GDP, inflation, unemployment), and studies how they behave, in particular how they react to economic shocks and policy decisions, over different time horizons. Two important subjects of macroeconomics can be identified: the study of the causes and consequences of short-run fluctuations in national income (the business cycle), and that of the determinants of long-run economic growth (increases in national income). We will see how macroeconomic models and their predictions are used by governments to assist in the development and evaluation of economic policy.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, we will develop a simple macroeconomic model that allows us to analyse the evolution of the main macroeconomic aggregates in the short, medium and long run. We will also critically discuss policy debates, so that we directly observe how economic theory can be used to understand the real world.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: For many consecutive years, the Creative Industries have been one of the fastest growing sectors of the Dutch economy. The core activities of the sector consist of the creation of form, meaning or symbolic value. Distinctive is the way this industry shapes these activities, by means of the creative innovation process. The creative industries include film, music, architecture, fashion, gaming, design, advertising and new media. It involves companies that find their justification in creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship. The course illustrates and discusses selected creative industries in the Netherlands and the challenges they face. It will give the students a view on what is characteristic of the creative industries in Netherlands, contrasting it to worldwide trends and developments. In a globalised world, the creative industries are increasingly important in the formation of national identity and symbolic value in this interactive course. The course surveys academic, industry, and popular scholarship to provide diverse disciplinary and applied perspectives. Each week a different industry will be presented (indicatively; Music, Architecture, Gaming, Digital Media, Film,  Visual Arts). The students will be asked to reflect on the specific developments and trends. We will  invite guest speakers (other faculty or industry practitioners) who will offer more insight into industry practices and on-going research relevant to the course.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Key concepts, approaches, developments, trends and challenges in the creative industries of the Netherlands.
• Analyze current developments and strategies in the creative industries using theories and concepts covered in the course.
• Reflect critically on the viewpoints and research materials presented in class.
• Reflect upon developments in the Dutch creative industries in the context of global trends.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89841,2019,Man & Society,Engels,Erasmus University College,,"['dr. G Noordzij', 'LIS Giel, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

We humans have an irresistible urge to explain our own and others’ behaviour, to attribute it to some causes and therefore, to make it seems orderly, predictable and controllable. Why do we behave, think, and feel as we do in social situations? How are our thoughts, feelings and behaviours shaped by others? How do we make sense of our social world and how do we become social? How do we see ourselves? These are the type of questions that the course Man & Society seeks to address. Obviously, a huge number of variables play a role in answering these questions and many disciplines employ scientific techniques to answer these questions. However, in this course we will try to answer these questions from a socio-psychological perspective and use quantitative research to investigate how and why certain (socio-psychological) behaviours occurred.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course deals with an important and relevant area of psychology, the social psychology. Social psychology is the scientific field that seeks to understand the nature and causes of individual behaviour in social situations. Social psychologists are interested in underlying social and cognitive processes as they are in overt behaviour. The central theme of social psychology is how people understand and interact with each other.
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Discuss the history and research methods of social psychology;
• Distinguish between cultures regarding the processes that underlie our thought, behaviour, and feelings in social situations;
• Apply theoretical concepts of this course in a more practical manner;
• Identify the components of the self and self-schemas;
• Define attitudes and how they develop and change;
• Compare the different routes of persuasion;
• Explain the theories and dynamics of group formation: social categorization and social identity;
• Understand the antecedents and consequences of stereotyping, prejudice, racism, discrimination, and genocide;
• Define aggression and its associated theories;
• Describe evolutionary approaches to helping others and the bystander effect;
• Understand the way people attach meaning to other’s and their own behavior;
• Explain the theories of attraction and romantic relationships;
• Write a scientifically sound research paper on a particular subtopic from social psychology.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89486,2019,Management Accounting,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. E Reusen', 'dr. F Elsinger']",,

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85563,2019,Management Consultancy & Policy Advice,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,"['AE Opperhuizen, MSc', 'dr. A Molenveld', 'dr. WH Voorberg, MSc', 'prof.dr. MW van Buuren', 'V Visser, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Public Administration experts, both in science and practice, have to contribute to complex societal issues. The knowledge students got in the first two years of their bachelor program enables them to analyse these issues. This module offers them new theoretical, conceptual and practical knowledge and competences to formulate advices and design solutions, to bridge the gap between the current situation (“ist”) and the desired situation (“soll”). Core of the module ‘Organisation and Policy Consultancy” is to enhance these analytical, design-oriented and advising skills of students.

This module builds upon the theoretical approaches presented in the various modules on “Policy” and “Organisation and Management”. Students have to apply their knowledge in policy processes and public organisations, to analyse complex policy and organisational issues and to formulate solution-oriented advices. They develop a repertoire of skills for professional advising. In addition they learn how to assess whether the conditions for successful policy or organizational change are present.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After successfully completing this course, the student is able to

column2: • Make a problem analysis of a complex policy and governance issue;
• Make an organisational diagnosis of a complex organisational and management issue;
• Apply the various steps of a design-approach for designing a policy or governance approach, an organizational change trajectory and a management strategy in a concrete case;
• Formulate a scientific valid and practical usable policy or governance advice;
• Formulate a scientific valid and practical usable organization and management advice;
• Reflect upon the quality of advising in the public domain;
• Formulate and assess the conditions for successful adoption and uptake of advising in the public domain.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89055,2019,Management Control,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. E Reusen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Management Control is about influencing the behaviour of managers to act in the best interest of the organization. Essentially, management control revolves around the question what techniques and instruments managers can apply to measure, guide and improve the economic performance of the organization. We therefore see management accounting as an important provider of management control, on the very essence of management: making decisions that secure the survival, viability and prosperity of the organization. The quality of managerial decisions depends to a large extent on the context in which these decisions are made and the information on which these decisions are based.

In this course students learn how performance measurement and evaluation procedures affect managerial decision making. The main focus is on the type of measures (financial and non-financial), target setting, and the link to rewards. Ample attention is paid to the fit with the organizational context, such as the strategy, structure and environmental uncertainties. Illustrations based on real-world cases are discussed, demonstrating when specific measurement systems are a good fit, and when they lead to dysfunctional managerial behaviour. Furthermore, the course shows how the measurement system, rules and regulations, and organizational culture need to be aligned with each other.
Management Control is an exciting and intellectually provocative topic area and one of the most challenging perspectives for the future.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students are able to:

column2: <li>
Understand the purpose of a management accounting & control system, and how it relates to strategy implementation and corporate governance;
<li>
Describe and apply the different types of controls (such as rules and regulations, compensation policies) dependent on the type of organization and its structure;
<li>
Approach management control related questions from different theoretical perspectives, using behavioural or economic theory;
<li>
List the crucial characteristics of performance measures, and apply the principles of performance measurement;
<li>
Identify the (dys-)functional effects and ethical aspects of accounting/budgeting systems, incentives and targets;
<li>
Evaluate and use different performance measurement and evaluation techniques, such as EVA and BSC;
<li>
Evaluate and judge the appropriateness/effectiveness of management control systems design based on circumstantial (contingency) variables, such as strategy.
<li>
Explain the main drivers behind the development and increased importance of inter-organizational relationships and related control issues;
<li>
Discuss and conclude in teams multiple viewpoints on a management control case, and present and defend the joint findings in a class setting.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87148,2019,Management and Leadership in Media Organizations,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. S Horst'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The current challenges in media organizations and the media industry, such as the growing mediatization of organizations and society, rising competition, and an increasing complexity of organizational issues make managing and leading processes and practices of strategy and change highly relevant.

Therefore, the course provides an overview of key theories and topics around strategy, management and leadership and works towards their reflective adaptation and implementation in media organizations and other mediated contexts. Students will comprehend and evaluate classical and modern approaches to competitive forces, industry analysis, resources and strategy processes and practices.

On this basis, we will discuss the possibilities of managing and leading individuals, teams and organizations through communication in strategic manner. Through the activities, students will apply these theories and approaches sensibly and creatively for developing successful actions in practice.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Students will gain knowledge and understanding  of:

column2: • Current concepts, approaches and theories of strategic management and leadership that are relevant for working in media organizations;
• How media organizations and practitioners strategically manage processes and practices around individuals, groups,  and organization-wide phenomena.
• Identify the need for and function of strategic management and leadership in their context;
• Apply strategy and leadership approaches and theories reflectively;
• Lead social and organizational action through communication.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87569,2019,Management challenges in international organisations,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. M Shemla'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The contact between individuals and organizations from different countries, cultures, and social groups has never been greater than in our time. In recent decades organizations have continuously globalized their operations, resulting in increasing frequency with which employees interact with colleagues and customers from different cultural backgrounds and ethnicities. At the same time, as a result of legal, social and economic shifts, workforce participation rates of women, minorities, and disabled people have dramatically grown, thus turning diversity into a strategic issue in organizations. Further, as executives operate around broader regions, global teams are formed to address the need to become globally competitive, and customers and suppliers operate across borders, the demands on global executives are ever growing.

This course is designed to help participants develop a deeper understanding of the issues that confront global managers today, and to prepare them for leadership roles in international organizations. Through business cases, experiential exercises, and real-life examples, the course strives to explore knowledge in leading diverse people as well as in leading global organizations. Emphasis will be placed on gaining awareness for the role of culture in organizations and on developing skills to manage diversity.

Each session is a module addressing a particular leadership challenge facing executives in the global arena (e.g., leading a diverse team, managing change, etc.). The teaching approach will vary, with a mix of lecture input, group discussion, case analysis, experiential exercises, and guest lectures.
The students will have the opportunity to learn from the experiences and insights of the following guest lecturers:
A. Mr. Jacques Kemp, Former CEO of ING Asia/Pacific, will talk about strategic issues in leading international organizations
B. Mrs. Josefine van Zanten, Senior Vice President Culture Change at Royal DSM
The course grade will be computed as a weighted average of five elements
e. Cultural immersion experience/Service learning project 30%
f. Optional task - Personal inquiry (Bonus of up to 0.5 points)
Assignments c, d, and g will be completed in teams. All other assignments are individual tasks.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Upon completion of this topic participants should:
- Acquire knowledge on managing people and teams in global contexts
- Experience first-hand accounts of the challenges facing leading diverse others
- Gain awareness of their own culture and how it influences the way they see the world
- Raise greater intercultural sensitive and empathy
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87443,2019,Management of Diversity and Inclusion,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. A Burmeister'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: This course will provide insights into the complex topic of diversity in organizations and will examine how diversity can effectively be managed in organizations. At the end of the course, students understand the core diversity theories and empirical research insights, can critically evaluate the operation and effects of diversity across individual, team, and organizational levels, and apply their learnings to real-world diversity challenges by identifying how human resource management (HRM) can contribute to the effective management of diversity in organizations.  </body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
<tbody>

column4: Having an understanding of the core diversity theories and most relevant scholarly insights on diversity.
Being able to approach diversity from a holistic perspective considering its complexity operating across levels (individual, team, organization) and contexts.
Being able to apply diversity theory and research to real-world challenges around the management of diversity.
Knowing how to have meaningful and evidence-based discussions about the management of diversity at work.
Using an evidence-based mindset to approach diversity management in the most effective way.
Being able and willing to critically reflect upon on one’s own perceptions about diversity.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87195,2019,Management of Media and Creative Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. HJCJ Hitters'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This seminar focuses on organizational aspects of the media and creative industries and the strategic conduct of firms. The central question is to what extent firms in the media and cultural industries are different from other firms with respect to initiating, managing and controlling business processes. This question will be analyzed from three angles. We will first systematically and critically assess the nature and structure of creative media markets, in which symbolic or experience value plays an important role and companies have to operate in a dynamic field of continuous technological, social and cultural transformations. Secondly, whereas most management literature centers on strategies of large cross-media corporations, in this seminar we aim at understanding the conduct and business ventures of small-scale enterprises and entrepreneurs (SMSE’s). These are mostly positioned at the beginning of the creative value chain: the phase of concept and idea creation and the first stages of production. After all, at this stage successful management of creativity is crucial to innovation. The third angle examines the relationship between incumbents and new enterprises in the media and creative industries. Here we will focus on issues such as innovation failure, routines, leadership and transformation. </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The specific character of organization and management in the media and creative industries.
• Current theories, approaches and debates in this field.
• Systematically analyze and critically reflect on fundamental and practical challenges in managing and organizing contemporary media and creative industries firms.
• Analyze independently an empirical case study.
• Find alternatives and solutions for challenges that media and creative companies are facing.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89424,2019,Management van technologie,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['prof.dr. DA Stam', 'SGM Langeveld, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Technologie is al eeuwenlang één van de belangrijkste pijlers van de economie. Zowel in de productiegerichte sectoren als in dienstverlenende bedrijven speelt technologie een belangrijke rol. Zonder technologische vooruitgang verliezen bedrijven concurrentiekracht. Managers staan voor de vraag of de huidige technologie in hun producten en productieprocessen nog wel up-to-date is, en wat de ontwikkelingen zijn van alternatieve technologieën. Moet de organisatie doorgaan met de huidige technologie of moet zij overstappen op een opkomende alternatieve technologie? Wat kunnen de consequenties zijn van deze keuze? In het kort, hoe kunnen managers relevante technologieën herkennen en op het juiste moment op de juiste wijze inpassen binnen het bedrijf?

Voor het vak Management van technologie gaan studenten een technologie strategie ontwikkelen voor een bedrijf dat hightech producten verkoopt. De studenten zullen de technologische voor- en nadelen van de huidige technologie in de producten analyseren, als ook van twee alternatieve technologieën die in deze producten kunnen worden toegepast. Om een keuze te maken uit deze technologieën moet de student ook het bedrijf en de omgeving analyseren. De studenten zullen verkennen wat de gevolgen zijn van deze keuze op de verschillende bedrijfsfuncties, denkend aan R&D, HRM, operations, supply chain, marketing etc.

Dit vak beschrijft hoe technologie benut kan worden in bedrijven. Hierbij gaat het niet om hoe op korte termijn aan een marktvraag kan worden voldaan door middel van technologie (“market pull”), maar hoe voor de lange termijn ontwikkelingen in de technologie kunnen worden benut (“technology push”). Voor aanvang van het vak selecteert elk studententeam een bedrijf uit een lijst hightech bedrijven. Elk bedrijf gebruikt een specifieke technologie in zijn hightech producten. Door middel van zelfstudie, verplichte bijeenkomsten en vrijwillige bijeenkomsten zullen studententeams het bedrijf en de huidige technologie analyseren (Opdracht 1), de alternatieve technologieën analyseren en de impact van het implementeren van deze technologieën op het bedrijf en de bedrijfsomgeving (Opdracht 2) en deze bevindingen integreren in een advies voor een technologie strategie (Opdracht 3). Dit advies zal schriftelijk gepresenteerd worden aan het bedrijf. De studententeams bestaan uit 6 RSM studenten. De teams worden begeleid door twee coaches; een ouderejaars RSM student en een Master student van de Technische Universiteit Delft. Let op! Er is geen schriftelijke toets voor dit vak, maar er zijn wel 4 bijeenkomsten welke verplicht zijn (inclusief bijeenkomsten waarin de kennis van de student wordt getest).</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na afloop van dit vak kan de student:

column2: • Samenwerken op een technologisch onderwerp;
• Een technologie gedreven aanpak gebruiken als een alternatieve manier om concurrerende producten/diensten en productieprocessen te ontwikkelen;
• Systematisch de impact van technologie op bedrijf en bedrijfsomgeving beoordelen;
• Een strategisch advies uitbrengen aan een bedrijf.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87446,2019,Managerial and group decision making,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. S Isaakyan'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

One of the most important actions performed by people in organizations is making decisions. Decision making takes place at many different levels of the organization and can have enormous implications for organizational functioning and performance. This course provides an in-depth view of several theoretical perspectives on decision making, at an individual level as well as at a group-level. In many business situations, it is not possible to solve a decision making problem by rationally analyzing all options. Therefore, an initial part of the course is devoted to understanding the nature, causes, and implications of human decision making limitations. Second, because decision making often takes place in a social context, a part of the course is devoted to social decision making and deals with how individuals coordinate their decisions in a social environment and how social influences affect decision making by individuals. Furthermore, decisions are often delegated to groups, because groups are supposed to possess more relevant resources like knowledge and perspectives. In reality, however, it is often the case that joint decision making is suboptimal. We will discuss the reasons why groups often do not use their potential, and how this could be improved. Finally, in many situations two or more parties that have different preferences need to make a joint decision. In the last part of the course, we will therefore discuss negotiation.

To meet course objectives, the course uses articles published in international journals, book chapters, lectures, and class discussions. Reading assignments provide essential background knowledge for class activities and must be completed prior to the start of each class (some classes will have additional material after class). Lectures will supplement information gained from the reading assignments and integrate course material.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course, students should:

column2: <li>
Have insight into main theories of individual, social, and group decision making;
<li>
Be able to apply these decision making theories to challenges facing current-day organizations;
<li>
Be able to solve decision making problems by translating academic knowledge and thinking into a theoretically and empirically anchored model and deriving recommendations.

column1: Strategic management is concerned with what is perhaps the most pressing issue for practicing managers: how can I make my firm outperform its competitors? To formulate such value-creating strategies, managers must identify a suitable business model, formulate growth strategies, identify core capabilities, and develop new ways of outcompeting their rivals. Firms also have to increasingly navigate more complex environments such as business ecosystems as well respond to rapid technological innovations, such as for example new digital technologies. This course allows students to acquire relevant knowledge about contemporary issues in strategy and to practice them through case discussions, group exercises, and guest lectures.

The emphasis in this class lies not on identifying the “right” answer, instead the focus is on creating a learning environment that stimulates students’ critical engagement with the study material. Teaching methods therefore include a combination of lectures, plenary discussions, guest lectures, and group exercises and case work. Students are expected to prepare the assigned material prior to each class in order to be able to be able to contribute to the interactive classroom discussions as well as being able to complete in-class group exercises.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: •    To examine how organizational context and managerial decisions are interdependent and critical to the successful strategy formulation;
•    To predict the impact of technological change on firms’ competitive position;
•    To evaluate what influences firms’ ability to successfully outperform its competitors; and
•    To formulate potential solutions to a key strategic problem.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>By studying relevant literature on cultural heritage management, students will gain knowledge of the intertwining character of heritage, tourism, economy, culture and (local) identity. Subsequently they will be challenged to apply their theoretical knowledge to concrete case studies which will require them to carry out field work on location. The course will highlight the strategies that can be put in place to ensure the better preservation possible of cultural heritage while stimulating tourism. Literature discussions, interviews and field trips will provide a varied didactic program with a hands-on attitude.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The purpose of this course is to provide students with the knowledge and skills to apply their theoretical knowledge to concrete real-life cases. Students become familiar with the major trends and challenges in the world of cultural heritage management and how heritage management could go together with place-making and the creation of sustainable tourism. Moreover, students will gain knowledge of the experiences of various actors in the field of cultural heritage management and their insider’s view on current developments.

A Gianoli', 'dr. CB Pennink', 'dr. OM Brilhante', 'FW Davidson', 'S Sharma', 'SN Welsh']",,"Inhoud

column1: The first set of lectures covers the infrastructure asset management concept and theories followed by infrastructure component of key  sectors, relationships between infrastructure and city planning, development and environmental quality, operation and maintenance strategies used to deliver a service according to a pre-determined level, and the one week workshop on green city. The workshop consists of two parts: part 1 includes the introduction of the IHS green city concept with special focus on the role of infrastructure to make cities greener followed by a debate using articles containing important elements of the theory of sustainability applied to urban planning and key concepts used to develop the IHS Green city concept; part two consists of a practical exercise to calculate the environmental performance of some selected cities.

After this initial part, the students will be split in two sub-groups (Water & sanitation) and (Energy & transport). The objective of forming these two groups is to provide more in depth knowledge on particular aspects of infrastructure sectors linked to these groups. The Financial issues such as the factors influencing the choice of financing methods for infrastructure projects, PPP arrangements, allocation and mitigation of risk, project evaluation (theory of changes) as well as capital structuring issues and governance will be covered for the two groups.

At the end or the specialization all the students will come again together for the half day case study on the Cheongyecheon Restoration Project, the three days exercise on business plan and the four days exercise on planning a city using the SIM City game.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: At the end of the course the participants should be able to:

column2: • Describe the role of infrastructure in helping cities to become greener.
• Identify and analyse the relationship of urban infrastructure with land use, economic development, investment, poverty reduction and environmental health conditions.
• Understand and analyse the role of infrastructure asset management in delivering a service according to a pre-determined level.
• Apply performance assessment methods to identify managerial problems affecting the good delivery of services and propose recommendations.

column1: Apply innovative models and mechanisms for financing  urban infrastructure to deliver good services and to  improve the green performance of cities</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87496,2019,Managing Innovation Strategically,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof. SM Ansari - Loan'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Increasingly, in today’s fast paced, converging world, sustained innovation is a necessity not only to thrive but also to survive. However, for most firms, the strategies and processes associated with innovation remain vague and are not professionally managed. As a result, most firms are unable to innovate and thus create new value, and among those who are able to create new value, few are able to capture it. In this course, we will learn why firms struggle to create and capture new value. Finally, we will share a number of concepts on how to implement innovation in an organization. The aim of the course is to provide a set of concepts as well as practical tools and processes that can be used by managers in their organizations to manage innovation better.
For further information and inspiration, please read the articles below:

column2: • Harvard Business Review (2002). “Inspiring Innovation.” Harvard Business Review, 80(8): pp. 39-49
• Dyer, J. et al (2009). “The Innovator’s DNA.” Harvard Business Review, 87(12): pp. 60-67

column1: Attendance is mandatory (as there is no exam) and your participation matters. The format is intense, but allows you to focus on the subject matter and to have engaging debates in the classroom. Applying the theoretical knowledge to real-life situations is a central aspect of this course. Therefore, it will include several practical examples.

All sessions will be highly interactive, with sufficient room for discussion, student presentations focusing on applying the theory to practical examples, and small group exercises. The approach is strongly participative. The instructor will introduce ideas, concepts and methodologies and discuss these in relation to your experiences and views. There will be a number of sessions where you are asked to experiment with the ideas and concepts that we introduce, so that you understand better how they work and how you may be able to apply them in the future. Hence, in the spirit of fruitful in-class discussion, students are expected to come prepared to class by having read the mandatory readings. In each session, there will be plenty of practitioner examples from different kinds of organizations to illustrate the perils and excitement of innovation and strategy. You are asked to think and debate critically.

In several sessions we will use case studies. In order to have an interesting session based on case studies, you obviously need to prepare these thoroughly. A good case preparation often requires three readings: one to get the overall story, one to do a thorough analysis of the problem, and one to formulate solutions.
Teamwork and leveraging complementarities – as in real life – are essential capabilities you should take away from RSM. You will be asked to form teams of 4-5 students.

Shaz Ansari is a Professor of Strategy at Judge Business School, University of Cambridge and Faculty at Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University. He holds a PhD from University of Cambridge. He serves on the Editorial Boards of Academy of Management Journal, Academy of Management Review, Organization Science, Journal of Management Studies and Organization Studies, and is member of CCGN – a confederation of University of Cambridge faculties, research centres and academics interested in corporate governance.  He is also a star member of Erasmus Research Institute of Management (ERIM). His research and teaching interests include institutional processes, logics and diffusion of practices; framing, social movements, technological and management innovations; ecosystem strategies, reputation management, and bottom-of-the-pyramid strategies, corporate governance and social, environmental and ethical issues in management including climate change. He has published in several leading academic journals including Academy of Management Journal, Academy of Management Review, Strategic Management Journal, Organization Science, Journal of Management Studies, Research Policy, Industrial and Corporate Change, Strategic Organization, and Organization Studies.

Professor Ansari's expertise in executive education includes strategic management, corporate governance, social innovation, and corporate social responsibility, technological and business model innovation. He has contributed to executive education programs in many organizations, including McKinsey, Airbus. Shell, British Telecom, China Development Bank, Nokia, Laing O'Rourke, UNICEF, Essex County Council, KLEC (Kuala Lumpur Education City).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
To understand the importance of innovation: Why is it relevant? What does innovation deliver?
<li>
To conceptualize what the different types of innovation are and how they need to be tackled differently.
<li>
To develop understanding of managing innovation internally and externally: How to manage projects or harness the power of users in the innovation process?
<li>
To get familiarized with disruptive innovations: What to do about them? How to disrupt an industry?
<li>
To help you think about the ways in which we can enhance the likelihood of innovation’s success in the market.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90011,2019,Managing Interactive Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. IF van Meerkerk', 'dr. MJ Nederhand']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course focuses on management in the context of interactive governance. Interactive governance is therefore a central concept in this course. Different perspectives on interactive governance are discussed, which also have consequences for how management in interactive governance is framed and which strategies are accentuated. Interactive governance pays attention to both participation and self-organization. The first means that governments organize citizen involvement in complex projects; the latter indicates that citizens themselves show self-organizing capacity for the preparation, implementation and maintenance of public services in different sectors for example: energy, health, water and urban development.

Regarding interactive governance, special attention will be devoted to leadership styles and different management strategies, like project and process management and boundary spanning activities that can be used in different situations and contexts. Interactive forms of governance are not self-executive due to various and oftentimes conflicting values, perceptions and interests. Connective and boundary spanning management is needed to stimulate and facilitate interaction between actors in interactive governance networks. In this course the concept of connective network management is discussed and explained. The main question this course addresses is: how is (network) management able to deal with the complexity (boundary-crossing nature of issues, dynamics, conflict of interests between actors, etc.) in interactive forms of governance and which (combinations of) strategies lead to good outcomes (innovation, effectiveness, legitimacy, and trust)?

The behavior, attitudes and skills of managers are discussed. What kind of activities do they exactly deploy, why and with which results? In complex networks of different (public, private, societal) actors an important feature of management is the establishment of relational capacity in order to connect different interests, values and viewpoints.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completion of the course students are able to:

column2: • To analyze the complex nature of interactive governance networks and processes (in terms of dynamics and interrelatedness);
• To distinguish and apply different perspectives on interactive governance;
• To understand the differences between government-induced (participation) and society induced (self-organization) interactive governance approaches and processes;
• To formulate critical conditions for effective, efficient and legitimate management of complex interactive governance processes;
• To determine management strategies fitting specific case study circumstances and situations (contingency approach);
• To formulate practical advice and guidelines for managers dealing with complex interactive governance processes and projects.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87440,2019,Managing NGOs,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['prof.dr. LCPM Meijs', 'PSM van Overbeeke, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: At the moment, Western governments are still making budget cuts in order to repair the damage caused by the financial crisis, handing over more responsibilities to its citizens. Meanwhile, businesses are reorganizing, which often means that they are slimming down, with many employees declared redundant. In the Arab world, citizens are calling upon their government to take its responsibilities. In North-Korea every step of the average citizen is still monitored. And the BRIC countries are experiencing economic growth like never before.

Nowadays, in many countries the power of government is fading. Governments have failed to solve social issues and have diminished in scope. In addition, we do not only look to government anymore to solve the social issues of our time. New parties are playing an increasingly decisive role in the political and social arenas: Non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

What is often forgotten as an important actor in society is the civil society sphere in which philanthropic nongovernmental and non-profit organizations are active. These organizations often focus on societal issues, such as the need for distributing medical care for those who have little access to it, to reduce poverty, reduce emissions, save the whales or advocate for human rights. Many of them are focused upon advocating governments and businesses to take their responsibilities. Others are collaborating with these organizations to gain additional resources. Just like business and governments, the context in which these NPOs and NGOs operate is very diverse (maybe even more diverse!). Just like for-profit organizations, many different types of NPOs and NGOs exist. Just like for-profit organizations, these organizations serve a mission and have their particular strategies. As such, just like for-profit organizations, these organizations need to be managed properly in order to achieve their goals. In this course, you will see however, that the way in which these organizations are managed, is completely different than in the for-profit or governmental sector.

During the elective, you will be provided with a theoretical and practical background of the management of philanthropic, non-profit and nongovernmental organizations. During a number of guest lectures, organizations will provide an insight into the management of their NPO or NGO. During these lectures, specific themes within management of philanthropic organizations are highlighted and investigated.

During the assignments you will be actively connecting research and practice based up on pragmatic real-life issues of NPOs. Although the cases are presented as fictive, experiences of previous years show that we are able to share your reports with many NPOs/NGOs in our network. Next to the lectures given by Prof. Dr. Lucas Meijs (Professor of Strategic Philanthropy and Volunteering) a number of guest lectures from the field are part of the elective. Moreover, fieldtrips to NPOs/NGOs will be arranged for you to be able to take a look into what really happens at these organisations.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After this elective, you will be able to
•    Understand the functioning and complexity of non-profit, nongovernmental and philanthropic organizations and the civil society;
•    Understand the management aspects of non-profit, nongovernmental or philanthropic organization;
•    Analyse the management aspects non-profit, nongovernmental or philanthropic organization;
•    Analyse specific challenges these organizations are facing in the contemporary context;
•    Evaluate your insights into practical issues of running a non-profit, nongovernmental or philanthropic organization;
•    Understand, analyse and evaluate the way in which the civil society sphere creates impact and interacts with and is related to the business and the governmental sphere.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89081,2019,Managing People in Organisations,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. JN Mell', 'HW Lam, MPhil']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

There is a growing realization that organizational success and the ability of organizations to gain a competitive advantage is critically contingent on effective management of people. This course covers the mainstream topics of OB and HRM by providing ‘principles’ valuable for managers dealing with human resource issues. The course builds on BA teaching in social and psychological processes and organizational behavior, and offers an in-depth treatment of key issues in the psychology of organizational behavior. Managing People in Organizations bridges cutting-edge theory with modern leadership and managerial practices. Emphasis will be placed on examining the relationship between theory and managerial practice.

To meet course objectives, the course uses selected book chapters, articles published in international journals, lectures, and class discussion. Reading assignments (listed in the syllabus) provide essential background knowledge for class activities and must be completed prior to the start of each class. Lectures will supplement information gained from the reading assignments and integrate course material. During the course, students are expected to actively participate in the class discussions.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Explain and understand core theories in the area of organizational behavior, including job satisfaction, intelligence and selection, motivation, teams, leadership, and organizational structure.
• Apply psychological/OB theories to challenges facing current-day organizations.
• Communicate theoretically sound and practical recommendations in a persuasive manner.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87492,2019,Managing Performance of Manufacturing and Service Systems,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. D Roy'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The main topics to be covered include the following ones
- Developing quantitative models and estimating performance measures
- Generating system insights and improving performance

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Companies of all kinds -- manufacturing or services – believe that their customers are most important and valuable assets. Strong customer focus is often identified as the most important
differentiator between the best and the worst companies. Hence, managing customer experience and guaranteeing a certain service level is of paramount importance.

Performance management in manufacturing and service companies is often complex because the performance is affected by coordination requirements among multiple resources and the customer. To understand the objective of this course better, consider “time” as the performance measure reflecting customer experience. For instance, in a manufacturing system, fulfilling a customer order in a timely fashion requires coordination among several resources such as, supplier (providing the raw material), planner (planning the machine capacity), scheduler (scheduling the job), worker (working on machine setup), and machine (processing the job). Therefore, lower is the coordination delays among the resources, better is the performance measure positively affecting the customer experience. Likewise, in a service system such as a restaurant, fulfilling a customer order in a timely fashion requires minimizing coordination delays among the tables (seating the customer), order takers (taking the order), and kitchen resources (preparing the food). Hence, to manage manufacturing and service system performance, there is a growing importance on analyzing the system and estimating the measures that are good indicators of customer experience such as customer “waiting time.”

This course will focus on approaches to estimate the performance measures and design systems for superior performance. The complexities in managing customer performance are further increased because of the sources of uncertainties present in the system such as uncertain number of customer arrivals. The students will also learn approaches to manage system performance in the presence of business uncertainties. Through this course, the students will develop skills in building quantitative models for manufacturing and service systems, which can be analyzed rapidly to provide insights for decision making. We will also try to incorporate behavioural aspects of service and manufacturing operations in the quantitative models. The skills will be developed through a mix of concept lectures, cases, experimenting with software tools, and a course project.  Some prior exposure to simulation tools will be helpful to keep pace with the course learnings.

The students will develop analytical thinking and learn to deal with practical issues while executing the course project, develop skills for quick performance analysis of systems, and also learn to develop managerial insights from models, which is an important skill to possess for executing complex on-the-job assignments in manufacturing and service organizations. The concepts discussed in each lecture will build on the learnings from the previous lectures. Hence, the students are advised to prepare thoroughly with the course material. A detailed course outline will be posted on Canvas.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89100,2019,Managing Professional Organisations,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. I Bogenrieder'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Professional service firms can be considered the most central change agent of our day and age: a new management theory is applied and spread by consultants, the physical environment is developed by engineers, controlling business is delegated to accountants and when all this does not succeed we rely on the help of lawyers. This indicates that professionals are ubiquitous in business life and justifies deeper research in the management of professional service organizations (PSF). In this course, we will consider professional organizations both for the ‘classical’, officially accredited professionals such as lawyers and accountants and the less ‘official’ professionals – also described as knowledge workers - such as IT experts, consultants and creative professionals in the field of marketing. We will classify them all as knowledge-intensive organizations.

The overall objective of this course is providing several perspectives on the working environment or ‘working context of a consultant’. The notion of ‘working context’ covers topics that are related to internal operations and organizational structure and processes as they are well known for professional service firms. The main question here is about the implications of working in a professional service firm. Another topic related to ‘working context’ covers methods and skills a consultant applies in a client assignment. We will provide an overview of methods as they are currently used in consultancy.

This course starts with an introductory session in the first week. During that lecture we will provide an overview of PSFs, their forms and markets and introduce interview skills and a questionnaire on PSF. Thereafter, every session in this course consists of a student presentation on the literature, followed by a discussion of the topic, formulating research questions and a final wrap-up. For the individual assignment you are asked to interview two real life consultants and use this information to write an essay.

column1: Public and private organisations are now confronting highly volatile multi-level political, economic and environmental realities. Global destabilization is underway involving key uncertainties characterized by climate breakdown, the dwindling influence of Western dominated international institutions, the rise of non-governmental influence and anti-establishment social movements, all in the midst of a new technological revolution which will see the rise of automation, artificial intelligence and the dismantling of traditional labour-capital frameworks. This course seeks to help you understand how societal organisations prepare for this future. It introduces you to the idea of how best to manage societal and institutional transitions within the context of global destabilization through robustly planning for strategically developed future scenarios. The course involves a twin track process of (1) lectures that give you a grounding on key uncertainties facing organisations and then (2) group work where you understand how to scenario plan based upon approaches used by organsations such as Royal Dutch Shell and a wide range of other private and public institutions. The written examination will then focus on the lecture material on key uncertainties in global societal and institutional transitions, whilst the group project examines your group work on scenario planning on behalf of a private or public organisation of your choice.

column1: <body>Learning goals. By the end of this course, students will be able to;

column2: • Identify the ways in which government, business and NGOs plan for future transitions
• Apply future scenario planning on behalf of an organisation
• Explain the changing roles of institutions in guiding society through transitions
• Explain how societal actors seek to exert influence by strategizing possible futures
• Explain key uncertainties such as climate change, the technological revolution and the rise of new powers
• Identify the main challenges and opportunities for governing transitions

column1: Utilize approaches to assess plans, strategies, policy documents and institutional arrangements for transitions</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87484,2019,Managing innovation with alliances and acquisitions,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. K Kavusan'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

As the rate of innovation increases and competition intensifies at the global level, even the largest companies require knowledge, ideas and capabilities from beyond their boundaries to develop innovations. Alliances and acquisitions are therefore becoming increasingly important corporate development activities for many companies to tap into external knowledge sources. Realizing the potential benefits of alliances and acquisitions in generating innovation outcomes is however no simple task: It is necessary to accurately evaluate of potential alliance partners and acquisition targets and different knowledge utilization strategies in terms of their suitability for a company`s innovation goals. The aim of this course is build a deep-level understanding of these issues and to provide opportunities to apply this understanding to real-life situations. The knowledge and analytical skills gained in this course will be particularly valuable for students seeking a career in high-technology industries, corporate strategy, and consulting.

The course consists of six sessions. In each session we will discuss a particular aspect of external innovation. Each session will consist of a lecture and discussion based on selected research articles related to the theme of the session, and a real-life case discussion to allow the application of research insights to real-life situations. The sessions are designed to facilitate students` contributions in the form of questions, arguments, and examples, which may lead to class-wide discussions.

Students will find opportunities to apply the knowledge and analytical skills gained in the course by working on an individual assignment, and on a group project. In these assignments, students will select a company in a high-technology industry, evaluate its innovation strategy with a particular emphasis on alliances and acquisitions, and develop an external innovation strategy with specific recommendations as to how to implement that strategy.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
To describe the role of alliances and acquisitions in developing innovation outcomes.
<li>
To select alliance partners and acquisition targets to achieve the innovation goals of a company.
<li>
To distinguish different strategies for utilizing external technological knowledge through alliances.
<li>
To develop an expertise in evaluating acquisition integration and its performance consequences form a technological knowledge point of view.
<li>
To develop business skills to convincingly present their ideas for innovation with alliances and acquisitions.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87490,2019,Managing the Family Business,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. G Criaco'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Family businesses are the most common form of business organization in almost all countries and industries worldwide. This is true not only for small, private companies. Founders or founding families are important controlling owners of large corporations listed on stock exchanges around the world. Famous examples of family businesses are IKEA, Harley Davidson and Heineken. As such, family businesses represent a very important force for the economic and social development anywhere in the world. Family control, however, raises unique challenges as well as value-creating opportunities for family businesses and their different stakeholders, such as customers, financiers, suppliers, partners, employees, board members and owners.

This course introduces students to the widespread, yet complex, phenomenon of family business. It touches upon several important themes, such as strategy development, succession, governance, conflicts, continuation, and more. The aim of the course is to introduce concepts and practical learning situations which may help the students to make sense of family businesses and to assist them in understanding and dealing with the challenges and opportunities faced by different family business stakeholders.

The course is specially designed for those who are interested in working in family businesses (e.g., as owner and/or manager) or with family businesses (e.g., as advisor and consultant), and for those coming from a family business background. Whatever their future role, students will find it useful to understand the uniqueness of these companies. During the course, the students will develop their own perspective on family businesses. After the course, the students should be able to apply in practice appropriate models and theories presented during the course, as well as critically examine models and theories regarding family business development.

The teaching methods used in this course consist of lectures, cases, group discussions, and team assignments. Students are expected to come to each session very well-prepared by having read the required readings and case for the session. Attendance at all classes is mandatory.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completion of the course, the student will be able to:

column2: <li>
Demonstrate knowledge about common characteristics and challenges of family businesses
<li>
Describe the main theories and concepts within the field of family business research and practice
<li>
Demonstrate an ability to analyze and apply family business theories and concepts to different critical situations in family businesses
<li>
Critically evaluate the use of concepts and models used to understand family businesses
<li>
Demonstrate an ability to reflect upon common challenges facing family businesses in practice, and develop a way to address these challenges

column1: In addition to these content-specific objectives, the student will be able to:

column2: <li>
Demonstrate an ability to work with others in a professional manner while attempting to achieve a common goal
<li>
Demonstrate an ability to think critically by identifying, analyzing and providing concrete solutions to complex problems, both in a team and individually

column1: The course is a mix of lectures, case studies, and games. The lectures are meant to explain supply chain models and concepts making use of both qualitative and quantitative methods. Qualitative methods involve theoretical frameworks, conceptual analysis, and evaluation of solution strategies whereas quantitative methods involve mathematical analysis, probability theory and basic concepts of microeconomics. Case studies depict a business scenario at a certain existing company; in which complex supply chain management decisions need to be taken. The situation is often partly described from the perspective of one of the key players in the decision–making process; furthermore, a certain degree of urgency is present as well. A teaching case requires very thorough preparation by the participant. Finally, students will be required to play game in a supply chain context, which will involve strategic and operational decisions.
To pass this core course, a participant needs to:
•    Individual and group assignments (including game performance and reports) (40% of the final grade);
•    Take a written exam (60% of the final grade).
