column1: Supply chain management has emerged as one of the major areas for companies to gain a competitive edge. Managing supply chains is a complex and challenging task, given the current business trends of expanding product variety, short product life cycles, increasing outsourcing, globalization of business, and continuous advances in information technology. This core course is intended for students with a strong interest in understanding logistics and operations – in either manufacturing or service industries – and the role supply chains and supply chain operations can play in business. The course will be particularly valuable for those who see their careers in operations/supply chain over the coming decade, or who see themselves consulting in operations/supply chain for client businesses. The course objectives are to:
•    Make you conversant in the language of supply chain management and expand your confidence in these area
•    Allow you to see the role of supply chain management in the overall strategy and performance of the firm by providing a conceptual, strategic view of supply chain design and operations

•    Analyze the underlying issues and trade-offs between the sourcing of raw materials, the manufacturing, storage, and transportation of products and the services required to fulfill customer expectations and the metrics of the firm
•    Provide you with quantitative and qualitative tools to identify, analyze and manage supply chain operations and issues
•    Analyze supply chains and supply chain operations to identify problems and improvement opportunities
•    Recommend and initiate supply chain improvement actions and projects
•    Enhance your team working and project management skills

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: Attendance is obligatory. You must compensate for missing a class with a 300 word essay critical reading response on the mandatory literature within 3 days after class.

In his ‘Compositionist Manifesto,’ Latour argues that the Anthropocene is closer to the 16th century than to the self-image of the modern world. Like a mannerist painting that stretches the rules of classicism to breaking point,’ Timothy Morton warns, ‘global warming has stretched our world to breaking point.’ Barthes finds in the mannerist grotesque a nature out of control. While we live in a thoroughly synthetic world, Sloterdijk points out, the ugly and sterile deformations already highlighted  already brought to the fore the composedness and artificiality ‘that the artificial, the artful, the human-made non-human is always much too complex to be merely aesthetically and organically pleasing.’ Kant and Hegel followed classical art critics of their time in reducing the explosion of ‘manners’ to artificial tricks or stereotyped ‘mannerisms,’ which led them to the rejection of mannerism tout court as kitchy, tasteless, and decadent. Much of the development of Romanticism and modern art would be based on the subsequent dialectic between art and its historical other. In the spirit of Baudelaire, it has been argued that mannerism is both the negation of art and its convex mirror, as if modernity is driven by something that escapes it and that can only be rendered visible in an oblique way. Adorno, Deleuze, Agamben, Nancy, Didi-Huberman and others, following the rediscovery of mannerism by the surrealist and expressionist movements, have all pointed, in varying ways, to the radical modernity of mannerist painting (Michelangelo, Parmigianino, Tintoretto, El Greco), music (Marenzio, Gesualdo), literature (Tesauro, Shakespeare) and architecture (Romano) and their resonances with artists such Bacon, Varèse, Schönberg, Boulez, Kafka, Beckett and so many others.

The aim of this course is to give a comprehensive overview of the intrinsic and extrinsic interferences between mannerist art (history) and Continental modal philosophy. It combines readings of Giordano Bruno, Bergson, Whitehead, Souriau and the philosophers mentioned above with extensive and detailed discussions of texts, art works and epistemological problems in art history and visual studies. It focuses on the historical and critical literature on questions of style, temporality, repetition, lateness, singularity, affect (and affectedness), artificiality, the problem of hysteria (from Charcot to Binswanger), the (neo-)baroque, early modern and modernist music, postmodern cinema, intermediality, metamodernism and contemporary craftsmanship.
The Late and the New: The Paradox of Style in Art, Art History and Aesthetics
The Major and the Minor: The Baroque and its Mannerist Interstices
Theories of disegno, and the Arts of Design

To identify, and work with, interdisciplinary resonances and stakes between art, art history, and philosophy.</body>

column1: <body>This course combines two specialisations: International Relations Theory and World History (or Global History). The perspective of the course is the highest possible level of international relations and global interactions, including empires, regions or continents. The two course books are examples of this type of historical research. Besides the course books, we shall discuss scholars that have produced historical perspectives on the rise and decline of empires and regions since about 1600 until present. Their publications contain global visions, covering both western and non-western countries. All authors use theories and/or paradigms to explain the history of these empires and regions. The focus is on therefore on 'Big questions, large theories and huge comparisons'. Some questions we will ask: What general theory or model is presented in the book? What is precisely new and innovative about the book? What is the motor behind historical processes and in what direction are we developing? Has the book stimulated related research by other scholars? How to relate these theories with research on lower levels of analysis, including states, NGO's and Multinational Corporations? What can we learn from these books for our own research (e.g. MA thesis)?</body>

column1: <body>This course focuses on the law and practice of marine insurance. Students learn about how ship-owners, charterers and cargo owners may obtain insurance cover against typical marine risks such as loss of or damage to ship’s hull and machinery, cargo damage and third-party liabilities. The course follows a theme-by-theme approach and draws comparisons between how these aspects are dealt with in case of a Hull & Machinery (H&M), a Protection & Indemnity (P&I) or a Marine Cargo insurance cover. The course adopts a comparative law perspective. Even though the starting point is the English Marine Insurance Act, this will be contrasted with provisions from civil law jurisdictions such as Title 7.17 of the Dutch Civil Code and from the Principles of European Insurance Contract Law (PEICL). Standard policy wordings such as the Institute Clauses and Club Rules are used as reference points where appropriate. The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases. Students need to prepare assignment that will be discussed during seminars. The course will be graded based on the assignments (20%) and a written essay exam (80%).</body>

column1: This course examines the complex legal relations and liabilities which arise when a ship at sea is in distress and/or suffers a maritime casualty. The course gives an overview of the many international legal instruments which (may) apply to various as-pects of a maritime casualty. It addresses the various mechanisms designed to pre-vent maritime casualties and marine pollution from occurring by raising the technical and safety standards of and on board of ships. These mechanisms include Flag- and Port-State Control, the Paris MoU and the role of Classification Societies.

Other subjects covered in depth include the law of Collision, Salvage, General Ave-rage, Limitation of Liability of the ship-owner, Civil Liability for Oil Pollution damage and Wreck Removal. The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases. The course will be examined on the basis of a written exam consisting of essay questions. Several lectures and/or workshops will be taught by guest lecturers from maritime practice.</body>

column1: In this course, the characteristics and management of markets are described in topics that include the marketing environment, components of the marketing mix, market segmentation, and planning. How do companies decide what products to sell or what services to provide? Is it important when the companies introduce the products/services into the marketplace? How do they know who will buy the product or use the service? What are some innovative new products/services that you think will experience growth in the next five years? What makes you think that these items will be successful? In completing this course you will explore some of the basic elements of marketing and answer these and other questions as you research and construct marketing functions as they apply to products/services currently on the market. The analytic part of the course moves from the general to the specific. The course is oriented around understanding the three C’s (customers, company and competitors), developing a strategy for the chosen product/market(s) and translating this strategy into more specific plans through the elements of the marketing mix, the four P’s (product offering, pricing, promotion and physical distribution).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course you will be able to:

column2: • Define the concept of marketing;
• Understand the fundamental principles of marketing, the key elements in developing and planning a marketing strategy, and the determinants of consumer behaviour;
• Master a set of analytical tools (i.e., frameworks, concepts, models, and techniques) for the evaluation and development of marketing efforts;
• Understand the practical relevance and use of the theory through exposure to examples of how companies organize their marketing efforts across a variety of business settings;
• Critically evaluate on organizational/ marketing problems by applying learned theories;
• Critically reflect on a number of ethical considerations raised by marketing practices and navigate ethical dilemmas in the marketplace.

column1: Het vak Marketing wordt niet meer aangeboden. Voor ouderejaars studenten die het vak nog niet gehaald hebben, is er echter wel de mogelijkheid om dit academisch jaar het tentamen en/of hertentamen te maken. Eerder behaalde resultaten voor de opdrachten, het marketing plan en de tussentoets blijven uitsluitend in 2019-2020 nog geldig.​ Zie ook de Overgangsregeling Economie en Bedrijfseconomie: https://my.eur.nl/en/ese/information-desk/regulations/transition-regulations

column5: Kennis ontwikkelen van de basis marketing concepten (zoals SWOT, marketing mix strategieën, marketing planning processen, markt onderzoek, consumentengedrag, branding, levenscyclus van een product, prijsstelling, adverteren/promoten, distributie).
Kennis ontwikkelen over hoe leidende bedrijven hun marketing strategie hebben ontwikkeld (door case studies).
Vaardigheden op doen om de kennis van marketing concepten toe te passen om relevante inzichten in verschillende marketing situaties te kunnen leveren (aan de hand van case studies).
Vaardigheden op doen om in groepsverband marketing concepten te analyseren, te presenteren, en te verbinden met verschillende marktsituaties (aan de hand van case studies en een marketing plan).

Vaardigheden ontwikkelen om in groepsverband de kennis van marketing concepten en strategieën van vooraanstaande bedrijven toe te passen om een marketing plan voor een nieuw product/service te ontwikkelen en te schrijven.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87455,2019,Marketing Analytics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. JMT Roos'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

“Marketing Analytics” refers to a broad range of activities that rely on data to improve marketing decisions. As the amount of data available to even the smallest companies continues to increase, companies of all types will continue to embrace this exciting and growing field.

Marketing analysts need to possess a diverse skill set. Although experience with programming and statistics is important, technical skills alone are typically not sufficient for success. Analysts must understand the business context they work in so that they can sensibly interpret results. Furthermore, marketing analysts must be able to clearly and persuasively communicate their insights to managers.

This course provides hands-on opportunities for you to develop and integrate these diverse skills. In the first half of the course, we emphasize the technical—reinforcing skills obtained from previous courses (e.g., statistical analysis of data, multiple regression) and developing new ones (e.g., advanced data visualization, demand estimation). In the second half of the course, we emphasize the application of these skills to solve managerial problems and communicate a recommended course of action.
Topics covered include the following (and are subject to change):
Week 1: Review of probability and statistics, and OLS regression; binary logistic regression; programming in R
Week 2: Designing and interpreting choice-based conjoint experiments; extending these ideas to estimate preferences and market shares using panel data; programming in R
Week 3: Psychological principles for data visualization and the grammar of graphics; using R’s ggplot2 package to visualize data and gain new insights
Week 4: Estimating the total market potential for new products with limited data; estimating consumer preferences using aggregated market data; manipulating, summarizing, and cleaning data in R

Weeks 5-6: Various topics in advanced market research, including: customer segmentation via statistical clustering; estimating customer lifetime value; introductory concepts in machine learning and forecasting, mining data from the web and social media, text-based sentiment analysis

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
Understand and explain the intuition behind basic statistical concepts, as well as more advanced topics
<li>
Manipulate and summarize data using R (statistical software: see www.r-project.org)
<li>
Draw inferences from data in order to answer questions relevant to marketing managers
<li>
Use R to graphically represent data and inferences; recognize and evaluate alternative presentation strategies
<li>
Explain and justify managerial recommendations to non-technical audiences through written reports

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86939,2019,Marketing Arts and Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['AC Crotta', 'dr. V Morea', 'L Marques', 'UZ Birsel - Birsel']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Marketing has become increasingly important as cultural and creative organizations need to generate more income from private sources such as ticket sales or sponsoring. They need to appeal to potential consumers by, e.g., having a clear and appealing identity, communicating and bonding effectively with their audiences, or offering arrangements attracting new audiences. Thus, arts organizations need to prove their relevance time and again in a world where the preferences, expectations and needs of their current and potential audiences are shifting constantly. Marketing is an indispensable tool to shape the relation with the public into a meaningful mutual commitment.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course will introduce students to the principles of art marketing. On the one hand, students will learn which characteristics of potential audience members determine their interest in the arts and how this interest may be increased. On the other hand, students are introduced to marketing strategies employed by cultural organizations and the rationale behind them.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A limited group of 20-25 students will be selected to follow an additional course that runs across the 3rd and 4th block of their studies. During the sessions, faculty members and marketing practitioners will discuss relevant and current themes in marketing, such as branding and social media.

Researchers within the department will present their own and others’ latest research in these areas and discuss it with the students. Practitioners and alumni will be invited to some of the sessions to give the programme a more applied flavour. The programme will also feature company visits. The sessions will be highly interactive and require a strong preparation consisting of reading and summarizing relevant literature. Cooperation will be sought with external partners, who will discuss the topics from their practical perspective.

Participation will be limited to the best students in the MSc programme of Marketing Management. The first step in the selection process will be a ranking based on all core courses (Blocks 1 and 2, weighted by ECTS). In the second step in the selection process, the highest ranking students will be asked to submit a motivation letter.</body>

The course is designed to complement the MSc course portfolio by offering more in-depth training in selected areas of particular interest. The programme is also designed to facilitate the transition from marketing student to marketing practitioner by offering ample networking opportunities and contacts with executives and companies.

column2: <title></title>

column1: The goal of this course is to introduce students to the marketing domain. Key questions that will be addressed during this course are: “What is marketing and the marketing concept?” and “How do companies develop a competitive advantage according to the marketing concept?” and “How is marketing affected by the use of social media?” Each session will consist of a blend of lecturing and (case) discussions. Students are expected to come well-prepared to classes and actively participate in the discussions.

During the lectures, concepts, frameworks, and theories will be presented and discussed, using practical examples to illustrate the ideas and highlight implementation issues as they are relevant for managers.

During the case discussions, you will be expected to analyse realistic problem situations in the form of business cases. While developing solutions, you will make use of core concepts in marketing and you will learn to apply them to a concrete case. As in actual practice, cases are characterized by a limited time frame for making decisions, incomplete information, and no clear ""best"" answer. The case method is essential to developing the kind of problem-solving and communication skills highly valued in the managerial practice. The ability to generalize from the specific case situations discussed in class to new situations that you may encounter is one of the foundations of management education.

During case discussions, a poorly prepared class invariably leads to an unrewarding experience for all involved. Thus, the long-term benefits from this course will be proportional to the extent that you make this course your project. This means that you are expected to come to class prepared and to actively participate. Specifically, you are expected to contribute to an informed exchange about the topic of the class and to have well-developed points of view about the cases and other reading material.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The primary objective of this course is for you to develop an in-depth understanding of the frameworks, concepts, models, and paradigms that collectively form the foundation for (strategic) marketing management. Secondary objectives include developing skills in the application of this knowledge for making decisions at the business level and developing an appreciation for the inter-disciplinary nature of marketing strategy.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86795,2019,Marketing Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. A Genevsky'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Marketing strategy is a complex business function that requires a balance of analytical and synthetic skills. This course introduces a series of frameworks and tools that can be used to a) solve general business problems and b) develop specific marketing strategies and programs.

The analytic part of the course moves from the general to the specific. The course is oriented around understanding the three Cs (customers, company, and competitors), developing a strategy for the chosen product/market(s), and translating this strategy into more specific plans through the elements of the marketing mix, the four Ps (product offering, pricing, promotion, and physical distribution).  Further, we will focus on Marketing as a source of positive change in the world – identifying needs and filling them effectively and efficiently in a way that generates positive outcomes for all parties .

The synthesis of all these elements is achieved through case analysis. In addition to bringing together the different theoretical elements in the context of concrete business problems, active participation in case analyses will (1) allow students to enhance their problem-solving and decision-making abilities in various areas of marketing and (2) provide an opportunity to develop, present, and defend their own recommendations, and to examine and discuss the recommendations of others critically.
This course prepares for all other courses that focus on value creation (such as strategic management), and in particular for the business simulation course in the second year.

• Understand why and how marketing is a central part of an organisational strategy by seeking to create superior value

• Understand and identify consumer motivations, needs and decision journeys
• Identify concrete real-world examples illustrating marketing theory in a multinational context
• Be able to analyze a complex business case with a small group of colleagues

column1: In today’s world oversupplied with media and entertainment content, the task of marketing movies, TV shows & channels, music, video games and comparable products is increasingly challenging. In a highly competitive environment, go-to-market strategies determine the product’s success or failure. In this course fundamental theories and perspectives on how entertainment is being marketed today are addressed.  Why and how is marketing media and entertainment products different to marketing products from any other sector?’ and ‘How is targeting fans different from reaching “traditional” target groups. These are central questions in the course. Furthermore, course topics include ‘positioning an entertainment property as a brand’, ‘building creative brand-centric strategies’, ‘creating products’ synergies’, ‘ecosystems and partnerships’, and ‘understanding how the digital world has impacted marketing and distribution’. The course allows students not only gain theoretical knowledge about the key aspects of leading strategic approaches but also to learn how to translate them into actionable plans.

column1: Individuals or households can choose to respond or not to a direct mailing, or they can choose between various brands in the supermarket. This course deals with econometric models for these qualitative variables. Examples of these models are the logit and probit models for binomial data and multinomial logit models for multinomial data. Also, ordered data, like those evolving from questionnaires, and count data will be considered.
The focus of the course is on model representation, model interpretation, parameter estimation and diagnostics.</body>

column1: <body>In this course, students will learn how to: (1) analyze marketing datasets obtained from expriments, questionnaires and secondary data sources, (2) select the appropriate statistical method for a given marketing research problem, and (3) interpret the output obtained from standard statistical software. The statistical techniques that will be focused are t-test, ANOVA, linear regression models, choice models, conjoint analysis and factor analysis. Students will gain hands on experience by applying the techniques to real datasets and draw managerial conclusions.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Knowledge of assumptions, interpretations, extensions, and workings of t-test, ANOVA, linear regression analysis, choice models, conjoint analysis, and factor analysis.
• Skills to analyze data sets with the appropriate marketing research technique using SPSS statistical tool.
• Skill to choose the appropriate statistical technique for a marketing research problem.

• Skill to interpret the results and derive recommendations using parameters obtained from a statistical package (e.g., SPSS) for t-test, ANOVA, linear regression analysis, choice models, conjoint analysis, and factor analysis.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89094,2019,Marketing Strategy,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. S Puntoni'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The purpose of marketing strategy is to develop and deploy an organization’s resources in the way that creates the most value for customers and other stakeholders. This course will help you to develop an in-depth understanding of key frameworks, concepts, and paradigms in marketing strategy and, just as important, to develop skills in the application of this knowledge. We will focus on two strategic problems, competitive positioning and innovation, and on two substantive areas, sustainability and technology. At a general level, the basic goal of this course is to help you make the transition from student to marketing practitioner and thus support your own goal of becoming a successful marketing professional. During the course, you will train extensively your case solving skills both in class, during interactive case discussions, and individually, in the assignments and trial exams. Student participation during the interactive lectures and meaningful contributions to the case discussions are essential. To facilitate interaction, the group will be split into three sections for some of the classes. Students will be tested by means of an exam and written case assignments (both individual and group).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: <li>
Understand how the context of marketing strategy is changing
<li>
Determine an organization’s competitive position
<li>
Recognize sources of meaningful differentiation
<li>
Understand how companies can become more innovative
<li>
Recognize potential ethical issues in marketing practice

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89095,2019,Marketing Strategy Research,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. X Chen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will focus on quantitative aspects of marketing research and how using quantitative tools can help managers address substantive marketing problems such as new product design, market segmentation and positioning. Also, the course aims to enhance students' understanding of how marketing variables such as price, advertising and sales force affect market share and sales, and how to develop marketing strategies based on quantitative analysis. Using a blended learning approach, the course tries to balance technicalities with marketing insights. Overall, the course is intended to make students well-informed users of marketing research, not becoming methodological experts.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<li>
Have a working “hands-on” experience with marketing strategy research techniques.
<li>
Be able to use (multivariate) statistical methods to support strategic marketing decisions.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86548,2019,Marketing Strategy in the Healthcare Industry,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. S Wendel', 'F Prins']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Many healthcare organizations are undergoing tremendous challenges at a fast pace. Main reasons are an increasing number of older people and people getting older (the ‘Grey market’), tightened budgets, and consumer empowerment. Effective marketing strategy is essential for any profit and nonprofit organization to stay competitive across all industries, including the healthcare industry with its many players. Some of the key producers and providers of goods and services of the healthcare industry are for instance the pharmaceutical and biotechnology firms, nursing / elderly homes and hospitals. The pharmaceutical industry will be one the players addressed in more detail during the course.
The main goal of this course is to introduce students to a variety of topics with marketing (strategy) and customer-centric thinking as key themes.
Some of the topics that the lectures will cover include:
1. Trends and challenges of the industry
2. What is marketing strategy and customer-centered thinking in healthcare?
3. Marketing strategy and the pharmaceutical sector
Check the video for more information:

column1: In het huidige economische klimaat leidt de sterk toegenomen concurrentie ertoe dat veel bedrijven het moeilijk hebben om te overleven. Ondanks deze onzekere tijden, zijn er enkele bedrijven die er keer op keer in slagen om succesvolle producten te lanceren en hun marktaandeel op systematische wijze te vergroten. Dit doet natuurlijk de volgende vraag rijzen: welke factoren zorgen ervoor dat het ene bedrijf succesvoller is dan het andere? In het vak Marketing Management bekijken we een van de belangrijkste redenen: veel van deze succesvolle bedrijven handelen namelijk vanuit een strategisch marketingperspectief. Door op systematische wijze in te spelen op de behoeften van klanten, presenteren zij een klantgericht producten- en dienstenaanbod dat duidelijk te onderscheiden is van de concurrentie.

In plaats van marketing louter te bekijken als de verkoop van bestaande producten en diensten, benadrukt dit vak hoe marketing management veelal een geïntegreerde strategie is waarbij de behoeften van de klant centraal staan. Daarvoor bekijken we hoe bedrijven de uiteenlopende behoeften van de klant kunnen analyseren en hoe ze op basis hiervan een strategie kunnen ontwikkelen waardoor ze zich kunnen onderscheiden van de concurrentie. Hierbij is het niet alleen van belang om goed uitgekiende producten en diensten te ontwikkelen, maar ook om doordachte beslissingen te nemen met betrekking tot distributiekanalen, prijs en promotiecampagnes.

column1: <body>Na het met succes volgen van dit vak:

column2: • Bent u in staat om te begrijpen en argumenteren hoe marketing een centraal deel is van de organisatiestrategie en hoe marketing een “force for positive change” kan zijn door het creëren van lange-termijn waarde voor klanten, bedrijven en de maatschappij in het algemeen;
• Hebt u een diepgaand begrip van de fundamentele principes binnen strategische marketing;
• Hebt u een diepgaand begrip van de centrale tactische elementen van marketing management;
• Bent u in staat om voorbeelden te geven van de gangbare onderzoeksmethoden in marketing management;
• Bent u in staat om te consumentenmotivaties, behoeften en beslissingsroutes te identificeren en te begrijpen;

• Bent u in staat om voorbeelden die illustratief zijn van marketing theorie of duiden op problemen met een marketingstrategie te identificeren, en aanbevelingen te maken op basis van relevante literatuur.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87459,2019,Marketing of New Products,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. YM van Everdingen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

New products, also called innovations, provide new ways to create value for customers, and moreover, it yields growth and profitability for firms. A huge percentage of a company’s sales and profit is generally earned by products that have been launched in the past five years. However, at the same time, many new products fail, and disappear from the market sooner or later after its launch. For example, why had Grolsch to withdraw the Cheersch home beer draft system from the market, while competing products, such as the PerfectDraft or the Beertender are still being sold? And, why did Nintendo’s Wii U never catch up with Nintendo’s projected sales shortly after the introduction? In contrast, what explains the success of a service like Airbnb or the Pokemon Go game. Within two weeks after its introduction, the game had 40 million daily active users. In other words, what makes one new product successful, while another new product fails to recoup its R&D cost? This question will be central in this course, and will be discussed form two angles, i.e., new product launch, and acceptance in the market.

During this course the students get acquainted with both conceptual and tacit knowledge of important methods in launching new products, and moreover in tracking the new product launch. Additionally, this course will provide a structured overview of the body of knowledge on adoption and diffusion of new products in the market place, and moreover, insights into how this knowledge can be incorporated in new product launch decisions.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
Select the most appropriate launch strategy for different types of new products, both for the domestic and the global market;
<li>
Understand both the consumer’s and the retailer’s new product adoption decision process;
<li>
Understand the diffusion process and the application of diffusion models across countries
<li>
Forecast the future sales of new products and the likelihood of a successful launch.

column1: This course is designed to provide students with advanced skills on the enforcement of law in the field of regulation of markets. In particular, students learn how to use economic arguments and economic evidence in real-life cases in courts and/or regulatory agencies. The course is organized in a moot court format. Students must take the role of plaintiffs, defendants, regulators or regulatees. They are supposed to base their arguments and decisions, both orally and in writing, on economic analysis of law. The topics, which are reviewed yearly, include inter alia competition law, product liability, mergers and acquisitions, financial and consumer law.
This course is open for EMLE students only.

column1: In this course, students decide on the topic and shape the outlines of their Master Thesis – an original and autonomously conducted academic study. Throughout, the emphasis is on the relationship between the research question, theory, data and analysis, and how to integrate these elements into a  well-structured research design. During the ‘thesis market’ the available supervisors of the programme will suggest themes and topics. These themes are either related to the expertise of the lecturers, but may also consist of questions/requests for research that specific cultural organisations might have. After that, students will come up with a topic of their interest. They will then develop this into a suitable, feasible and well-argued research proposal, which will be the basis of the work on the actual Master Thesis.

This course consists of two components. On the one hand, there is a personal trajectory in which students build their proposal through consecutive assignments. There is room for trial-and-error and individual feedback is provided in the various steps. On the other hand, the meetings serve as regular collective checkpoints to streamline the process. In the meetings, the emphasis is on the general requirements and possible hurdles. In doing so, ample attention is paid to the content-related and formal criteria, as well as the time planning, to make sure that the Master Thesis (and the Master Thesis proposal) is in line with the programme’s requirements. Therefore, we will consider (and in some cases freshen up) topics such as conceptualizing, argumentation, searching for and integrating literature, various methodologies, and academic writing.

column1: Students investing fully in this course will be able to write a clear, well-structured and feasible research proposal for their Master Thesis, including an introduction (research question and relevance), a theoretical framework and a data and methods section. In the process students will identify a topic, formulate a concise research question, search for, find and select relevant literature, operationalize theoretical concepts and come up with a suitable method of research.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87006,2019,Master Thesis Class PCT,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['N van Es, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

First, we will explain all the content-related and formal criteria the Master Thesis and master thesis proposal have to fulfil as well as the time planning. Second, during the ‘thesis market’ the lecturers of the programme will present potential thesis topics which lie on the intersections between place, culture and tourism that students can – but do not have to – choose as their Master Thesis topics. These themes are either related to the expertise of the lecturers or consist of questions specific cultural organisations might have. Third, we will elaborate on turning a relevant and feasible topic into a research question. During the last two meetings, students will start writing their master thesis proposal. Fourth, students learn to search, find and select relevant literature and make efficient use of various digital search tools. The emphasis, however, will be on the relationship between the research question, theory, data and analysis, and how to integrate these elements into a well-structured and logical research design.  Fifth, students will receive tips and tricks and practice their writing skills and learn to monitor and optimize the writing process.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students investing fully in this course will be able to write a clear, well-structured and feasible research proposal for their Master Thesis, focusing on the intertwined relationship between place, culture and tourism. This includes an introduction (research question and relevance), a theoretical framework and a data and methods section. In the process students will be able to identify a topic, formulate a concise research question, search, find and select relevant literature, operationalize theoretical concepts and come up with a suitable methodology.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: : This course has two main objectives, i.e.to train students in essential academic skills and to guide them towards their MA-thesis: Firstly, students get the opportunity to learn, train and improve a number of essential academic skills. They are introduced and trained in techniques of argumentation and reasoning. Essential basics of academic writing, such as citation techniques, are rehearsed and students are introduced to the skills of philosophical writing. Last but certainly not least, students get the opportunity to train and improve their presentation skills.

Secondly, students are guided towards their MA-thesis in a milestone-process. In this process they learn how to choose a suitable topic for their thesis before they proceed in specifying a tractable research question. In a next step, students are guided in further developing their question into a thesis outline. They present their outline to their peers in order to receive first feedback before embarking on the process of writing their thesis in block 4. </body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89570,2019,Master Thesis Tutorial Group,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. B Leeuwenburgh', 'J van der Klaauw, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In this Academic Skills Course students will guided towards the actual writing of their thesis in block 4. The course consists of four tutorials sessions, three milestones and thesis writing circle meetings. In the first tutorial session students are stimulated by means of brainstorm sessions to come up with a preliminary thesis topic. In the second session two members of the faculty staff will give practical information about doing research. ‘How to write and cite’ is addressed in the third session. During the last session students will give a short presentation of their thesis and research. Afterwards feedback will be given by other students and lecturers. Instructions for the three milestone assignments will be given during the tutorial sessions. After the last tutorial sessions students will form separate thesis circles under the supervision of a tutor.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The principal objective of the Master thesis is to familiarise students with carrying out business and management research and to allow students to gain a deeper understanding of a topic of their interest. As such, the thesis contributes to the student’s specialisation in a particular area. Knowledge and understanding of business and management research is relevant in both business and academic settings. Training in business research methods prepares students to systematically investigate and solve a management dilemma (i.e., any problem or opportunity that requires a management decision) and to evaluate whether studies and proposals prepared by third parties (e.g. consultancy agencies) can serve as a basis for a management decision.

Through the Master thesis process students will also develop their competencies and skills in writing and communicating their ideas. Finally, time management and self-management are important managerial skills, which the thesis period provides an excellent opportunity to develop and test.</body>

column1: <body>During this course, students learn about the structure of a master thesis and about the available master thesis topics. Students obtain comprehensive guidance in an information and Q&A session before they select their topic. During and after the session, students can ask questions as well as ask for additional advice. After the orientation session, students select their master thesis topic from the topic list, read the recommended literature and independently prepare a draft of their research idea (max 3 pages), which has to be submitted to the coach. The research idea can be based either on the pre-defined questions indicated in the topic description or on own ideas within the indicated topics, depending on the capabilities, creativity and ambition of the individual students. During the meeting, the coach provides the student with feedback on the research idea, which students have to incorporate. Students have to hand in a document containing the introduction and literature review chapters of the thesis. Students pass this stage if this document is of sufficient quality.</body>

column1: After the course, students should be able to;
»        summarize the literature relevant to the chosen master thesis topic;
»        identify one or more gaps in the literature;
»        formulate research questions to address the identified gap(s) in the literature;
»        explain the contribution of the proposed research to the literature;
»        describe the academic and practical relevance of the proposed research;
»        identify the methods and data sources necessary to conduct the proposed research;
»        write an introduction and literature review containing all of the above elements.</body>

column1: (For Dutch students, see below) Writing a master's thesis based on a student's own research is the central feature of the master's programme. The master's thesis enables students to demonstrate their abilities to contribute to scholarly debate of a particular subject according to academic standards.
The following are additional requirements that the master’s thesis must satisfy:
•   the research is based on a clearly formulated problem and research questions;
•   the research is grounded in theories and methodologies from the discipline, or theories and
methodologies relevant to the specific theme;
•   these theories and methodologies will be critically assessed in relation to the formulation of the problem;
•   previous research concerning the chosen theme will be specified, summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to one's own research;
•   the literature, primary and secondary sources, and other information and data will be presented systematically and in relation to each other;
•   the thesis will consist of an introduction, various chapters in which the findings will be discussed, a conclusion, bibliography and (possibly) appendices;
•   the research will result in a clear, succinctly written conclusion;
•   the literature, sources and other information and data will be accurately listed in footnotes and, if
•   the thesis will be written in polished, accurate Dutch or English;
•   the thesis will consist of approximately 25.000 words (+/- 10 %), not counting the title page, table of

Het schrijven van de master thesis staat centraal tijdens de masteropleiding. In de master thesis laten studenten zien dat zij op basis van eigen, oorspronkelijk onderzoek een bijdrage kunnen leveren aan het wetenschappelijke debat over een bepaald onderwerp uit het eigen vakgebied. Overige eisen die worden gesteld aan de master thesis zijn:
•   het onderzoek is gebaseerd op een helder geformuleerde probleemstelling en daaruit afgeleide
•   het onderzoek is gestoeld op theorieën en methoden uit het vakgebied, dan wel theorieën en methoden die voor dit specifieke onderwerp relevant zijn;
•   deze theorieën en methoden worden in de thesis besproken en beargumenteerd in relatie tot de probleemstelling;
•   eerder onderzoek rond het gekozen onderwerp wordt aangegeven, samengevat en besproken voorzover relevant voor het eigen onderzoek;
•   gebruikte literatuur, primaire en secundaire bronnen, overige gegevens en data worden systematisch gepresenteerd en aan elkaar gerelateerd;
•   de thesis bestaat uit een inleiding, diverse hoofdstukken waarin de bevindingen worden besproken, conclusie, literatuurlijst en (eventueel) bijlagen;
•   het onderzoek mondt uit in een heldere, bondig geschreven conclusie;
•   literatuur, bronnen en overige gegevens en data worden nauwkeurig opgegeven in voetnoten,
•   de thesis is geschreven in verzorgd en accuraat Nederlands of Engels;
•   de thesis kent een omvang van 25.000 woorden (+/- 10 %), exclusief titelblad, inhoudsopgave,

column1: The thesis is an individual assignment about a subject from your Master's specialisation. More information about thesis subjects, thesis supervisors and the writing process can be found on the Master's thesis website.

column2: <title></title>

• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which they can initiate and perform a literature review which is useful for their research project.

• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which methods and techniques of scientific research in the field of accounting, auditing, control or finance can be applied to their own research topic.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the application of up-to-date qualitative or quantitative research methods.

• Students are able to: formulate a clear research question based on relevant academic concepts and theories, and legitimized by up-to-date academic or social developments as well as to formulate hypotheses in a systematic and valid way.

• Students are able to: analyse and interpret data in an accurate, reliable, comprehensive and verifiable way and to formulate conclusions which sufficiently take into account presuppositions, basic principles and the limitations/opportunities of the selected methodology.

• Students are able to: report on research findings in a logical and consistent way and give a clear oral explanation of the research project as well as to answer critical questions about the research in a convincing manner.

column1: <body>The master’s thesis is the major project in the entire programme. With their master's thesis, students demonstrate that they are able to contribute to academic and sophisticated professional debates on a specific subject. Each student that achieved satisfactory results in his/her coursework will be appointed with a supervisor. Supervisors will provide personal advice on various occasions to ensure that students can make reliable progress. The master's thesis will fulfil the following criteria:

column2: • it is based on a clearly formulated research question;
• it relates to theories and methodologies of the discipline, or theories and methodologies relevant to the specific theme;
• the selected theories and methodologies are discussed and justified in the thesis with respect to the formulation of the problem;
• previous research concerning the chosen theme are summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to the original aspects of the thesis;
• the academic literature as well as all other information and data used are systematically presented and related to the main theme of the thesis;
• the thesis contains a clear, succinctly written conclusion;
• the thesis contains an introduction, various chapters in which theory, method and the findings are discussed, a conclusion, a bibliography and (possibly) appendices;
• the literature, sources and other information and data are accurately referenced;
• the thesis is written in polished, accurate English;
• the main text of the thesis does not far exceed 20.000 words.

<body>The master’s thesis is the major project in the entire programme. With their master's thesis, students demonstrate that they are able to contribute to academic and sophisticated professional debates on a specific subject. Each student that achieved satisfactory results in his/her coursework will be appointed with a supervisor. Supervisors will provide personal advice on various occasions to ensure that students can make reliable progress. The master's thesis will fulfil the following criteria:

column2: • it is based on a clearly formulated research question;
• it relates to theories and methodologies of the discipline, or theories and methodologies relevant to the specific theme;
• the selected theories and methodologies are discussed and justified in the thesis with respect to the formulation of the problem;
• previous research concerning the chosen theme are summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to the original aspects of the thesis;
• the academic literature as well as all other information and data used are systematically presented and related to the main theme of the thesis;
• the thesis contains a clear, succinctly written conclusion;
• the thesis contains an introduction, various chapters in which theory, method and the findings are discussed, a conclusion, a bibliography and (possibly) appendices;
• the literature, sources and other information and data are accurately referenced;
• the thesis is written in polished, accurate English;
• the main text of the thesis does not far exceed 20.000 words.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Writing a master's thesis is the central feature of the research master's programme. The master's thesis enables students, based on their own original research, to demonstrate their abilities to contribute to the academic debate of a specific subject in their field of study. The following are additional requirements that the master's thesis must satisfy:

column2: • the research will based on a clearly formulated problem and subsequent research questions;
• the research will be based on theories and methodologies relevant to the field of study and the specific theme;
• the theories and methodologies will be discussed and argued in the thesis with respect to the formulation of the problem;
• previous research concerning the chosen theme will be indicated, summarised and discussed in so far as it is relevant to one's own research;
• the literature used, primary and secondary sources, other information and data will be systematically presented and interrelated;
• the research will result in a clear, succinctly written conclusion.

column1: The master's thesis should have the format of an article for an international peer-reviewed academic journal. As such it should meet the following requirements:

column2: • the article will contain a clearly stated research problem and research question(s); a description of the scientific/ background and relevance of the research question(s); an outline of the methods of data collection and analysis; a presentation and discussion of the findings, and a conclusion highlighting the scientific relevance of the findings and how these relate to the existent literature on the topic;
• the literature, sources and other information and data will be accurately listed in footnotes and the references, and, if necessary, in separate appendices;
• the article will be preceded by an abstract (200-400 words) and five key words;
• the article accords with the established formats of the relevant journal(s) within the disciplinary and thematic field that fits the research topic.
• the article will be written in polished, accurate English;
• the article will consist of a maximum of 10.000 words, excluding footnotes and references, tables and figures, abstract and key words.
<title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Students have developed the knowlegde and skills to:​

column2: • Formulate an original and relevant scholarly problem in his or her field of study
• Draw up an appropriate research proposal, including a positioning of the thesis in currently scholarly discussion, a well-argued research strategy, and time plan
• Organize the research set-up (empirical and/or fieldwork research)
• Use current social-scientific methods and techniques to collect and analyze the required information and data
• Report on the results/findings in a coherent and reflexive way
• Evaluate the conclusions and choices made during the research process
• Write an academic article in English, to be submitted for publication to an international peer-reviewed academic journal

column1: Your thesis is the ‘masterpiece’ of your master’s degree in Sociology. The master’s thesis is an empirical study demonstrating that you have all the necessary competences to independently formulate sociologically relevant research questions, to select and apply suitable theoretical frameworks and methodological approaches consistent with the disciplinary and legal norms relating to privacy and ethics, and to communicate your work in a scientific and professional manner.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>In the process of writing your master’s thesis proposal, conducting the research necessary to answer your research question(s), and reporting on the study conducted in your master’s thesis, you will learn:

column2: • To formulate a suitable and sociologically relevant problem statement;
• To provide an overview of the extant literature in the chosen research subfield, resulting in a detailed and specific research question(s);
• To differentiate between descriptive and explanatory research questions;
• To use sociological theory and empirical findings to develop hypotheses and/or sub-questions, which constitute the basis for your theoretical framework;
• To create an appropriate research design to answer your research question(s);
• To assess the feasibility of your research design;
• To demonstrate and document the proper, careful consideration of the ethics and privacy implications of your study;
• To reliably operationalize the core concepts of your study;
• To independently conduct empirical research using secondary or primary (self-collected) data, using suitable analytical methods and techniques;
• To discuss the theoretical and empirical value of your study and evaluate your study’s sociological and societal relevance;
• To clearly and adequately orally communicate your thesis proposal to both expert and lay audiences.

The final thesis takes the form of an individual research project. The topic can be chosen by the student, but it needs to be related to one or more of the MGN courses and topics. The thesis must  have an a recognizible  governance topic as research object and focused on analyzing this governance topic

Note that an internship is not part of the MGN program (but in special cases it is possible to include this. But this always needs a positive decision of the supervisors of the master program). .At the start of block 3, students will be matched with a supervisor, who will very often be one of the lecturers that taught the mandatory courses of this master program. This is coordinated by the MGN program directors and depends on the expertise and thesis-load of potential supervisors. After the manuscript has been approved by the supervisor, he or she will involve a second reader. When both approve the research project and all requirements of the MGN master have been satisfied, the thesis will be defended in front of the delegated examination board.</body>

column1: <body>Students attending the Master Class will get familiarized with the complexity of the actual financial/insurance world and will be able to understand this and to form their own opinion. Lectures will be presented by specialists from Allianz Benelux and speakers from other leading organisations. This combination will guarantee quality and independency of the course. Each lecture contains a practical part in the form of a case or small assignment. Attending the Master Class will reward students with a certificate provided by the Erasmus School of Economics.</body>

column1: <body>This extracurricular Master Class is organized in cooperation with Allianz. It is meant for students who want to know more about a very interesting and dynamic discipline: actuarial sciences. Actuaries are experts in analysing the past, modelling the future, assessing the risk involved by using mathematical and statistical models and communicating what the result means in financial terms. In the Master Class the most important aspects of the actuarial profession will be presented by bringing together theory and practice.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87870,2019,Masterclass Togamaster,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. B de Jong'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>De masterclasses worden verzorgd door de partners die verbonden zijn aan Toga aan de Maas. Ze vinden plaats aan de Erasmus School of Law of inhouse bij de parnters. Soms zullen de studenten uit publiekrechtelijke hoek samen met de privaatrechtelijk studenten deelnemen aan de masterclasses. Gedurende deze masterclasses zal op belangrijke leerstukken worden ingegaan vanuit rechtsvergelijkend perspectief. Zo kan er vanuit verschillende perspectieven bekeken worden hoe frauderende bestuurders aansprakelijk gesteld kunnen worden. Fiscaal gezien werkt dit natuurlijk anders uit dan strafrechtelijk. Studenten die deelnemen aan het programma van Toga aan de Maas worden geacht problemen te signaleren en bekijken vanuit verschillende invalshoeken. Ook kunnen de studenten masterclasses volgen die meer zijn toegespitst op hun achtergrond.  Op deze manier wordt de voor een excellente master typische verdieping aangebracht binnen de privaatrechtelijke en binnen de publiekrechtelijke vakken.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Aanleren van specifieke toga vaardigheden
• Verdieping in gerichte ethiek (concrete dillema's)

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87875,2019,Masterclass actualiteiten gezondheidsrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr.dr. AP den Exter', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit vak wordt het onderwijs primair verzorgd door gerenommeerde juristen (advocaten, ziekenhuisjuristen, etc.) werkzaam in de praktijk van het gezondheidsrecht. Zij laten de studenten kennismaken met actuele ontwikkelingen op de verschillende deelterreinen van dit rechtsgebied: het zorgverleningsrecht, het zorgverzekeringsrecht en het zorginkooprecht. Van de studenten wordt gevraagd hun eerder opgedane kennis van deze deelgebieden van het gezondheidsrecht toe te passen op actuele vraagstukken. De studenten krijgen van de gastdocenten casuïstiek voorgelegd, die zij moeten behandelen in wekelijks in te leveren werkstukken. De rechtsvragen die de studenten krijgen voorgelegd, zijn ontleend aan die van de rechtspraktijk van de gastdocenten. Het onderwijs vindt deels plaats ten kantore van de praktijkjuristen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Doel/Purpose:

• De student heeft kennisgemaakt met de praktijk van het gezondheidsrecht en de laatste ontwikkelingen op alle deelterreinen van dit rechtsgebied. Hij heeft weet van de relevante rechtspraak en nieuwe ontwikkelingen op deze terreinen en is in staat om deze ontwikkelingen te kunnen plaatsen en op hun relevantie te kunnen beoordelen.

• De student beschikt over juridische en algemene academische vaardigheden, waarbij kennis van het gezondheidsrecht, inzicht en probleemoplossende vermogens kunnen worden toegepast in nieuwe of onbekende omstandigheden binnen de bredere (of multidisciplinaire) context van dit rechtsgebied.
• Dit betekent dat
• de student wet- en regelgeving op casuïstiek kan toepassen en een logisch antwoord kan formuleren op de rechtsvragen bij een casus.
• de student op basis van een actuele casus de rechtsvraag kan formuleren;
• De student geeft bij het doen van de praktijkopdrachten blijk van creativiteit en zelfstandigheid.
• De student durft een eigen mening te uiten tijdens colleges, door middel van het doen van onderbouwde uitspraken met betrekking tot de behandelde stof.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/84206,2019,Masterclass: Advances in Genomics Research (ESP63),Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['prof. dr. A.G. Uitterlinden', 'prof. dr. R.M.W. Hofstra', 'prof. dr. V. Bonifati']",,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87451,2019,Mastering Networks for Innovation,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. S Tasselli'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Social network connections and positions constrain and facilitate outcomes of importance to individuals, groups, and organizations. For instance, Networks and relationships are not only critical to access and exchange information and resources but also imperative to organize support and to market innovative ideas.

In the lectures of this course we focus on social networks and relationships more generally and on when and how they influence innovation in particular. We address different network structures (e.g., size, tie strength, centrality, or density) across different levels (e.g., individual-, dyadic-, team-, or organizational-level) in different innovation phases (e.g., idea generation, implementation, or diffusion). Furthermore, we discuss important differences between online and offline social networks and explore the general drivers and antecedents of social networks and relationships.
In workshops you get familiar with the UCINET and NetDraw software. These are tools that help you analyze and visualize social networks.

In a project that is run in co-operation with an organization, you will apply the insights of this course to craft a strategy that utilizes the power of social networks and you will give adcice on how the network should and could be developed in the furture.

The learnings of this course are especially relevant for prospective consultants and innovation managers who need to analyze and shape change processes and intra- or inter-organizational collaboration projects. For students interested in examining, understanding, and optimizing their network position and structure, the learnings are of equal use.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
You will get equipped with the latest insights and theories on the drivers and consequences of social networks for innovation.
<li>
You will learn state-of-the-art tools to analyse and visualize social networks.
• You will understand the advantages and disadvantages that certain positions in a network have.
• You will be able to give advice about the changes that are necessary to take full advantage of a network position.

column1: De scriptie is een individueel werkstuk over een onderwerp uit je Masterprogramma. Meer informatie over scriptieonderwerpen, scriptiebegeleiders en het schrijfproces is te vinden op de Masterscriptiewebsite.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Studenten leren zelfstandig verdiepende kennis op te doen over een fiscaal of fiscaal-economisch onderwerp en over dat onderwerp een onderzoek doen opzetten en zelfstandig doen uitvoeren, d.w.z. van het opstellen van een onderzoeksvraag tot het afronden van het onderzoeksverslag.
• Studenten leren een relevante onderzoeksvraag te formuleren op het terrein van het zelfgekozen fiscale of fiscaal-economische onderwerp.

• Studenten leren over hun onderzoek in overeenstemming met de geldende academische standaarden correct en bondig op logische en consistente wijze schriftelijk verslag te doen en dit vervolgens mondeling overtuigend te presenteren en te verdedigen.

column1: <body>Het vak Materieel strafrecht borduurt voort op het B1-vak Inleiding strafrecht. In het onderhavige vak wordt dieper ingegaan op het materiële strafrecht. Het overkoepelende thema van het vak betreft ‘strafrechtelijke aansprakelijkheid’. Het vraagstuk wie, wanneer en waarvoor strafrechtelijk aansprakelijk is, valt uiteen in verschillende leerstukken zoals schuld, poging, deelneming en strafuitsluitingsgronden. De student doet niet alleen kennis op over de centrale begrippen en leerstukken van het materiële strafrecht, maar leert die kennis ook te gebruiken en toe te passen op een casus. Het analyseren van concrete materieel strafrechtelijke problemen (casuïstiek) vormt een belangrijk onderdeel van het vak.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• de beginselen, leerstukken en systematiek van het materiele strafrecht beschrijven, herkennen, definiëren, analyseren en beoordelen;
• theoretische achtergronden, historische ontwikkelingen en maatschappelijke aspecten van het materiele strafrecht beschrijven, verklaren en analyseren;
• verschillende materieel strafrechtelijke begrippen onderscheiden, analyseren en beargumenteerd toepassen op een concrete strafrechtelijke casus;

• beoordelen welk materieel strafrechtelijk leerstuk in een concreet geval van toepassing is en motiveren of aan de in de huidige relevante wetsbepalingen, literatuur en jurisprudentie gestelde voorwaarden is voldaan, en;
• de daarvoor relevante jurisprudentie opzoeken, analyseren, toepassen en in onderling verband kritisch beoordelen.

The course consists of two parts.  It begins with a refreshment on classical microeconomics analysis and develops into the utility maximization theory, in Part 1.  The necessary mathematical tools (ODE) are briefly presented. The main analytical emphasis is on restoring underlying preferences from empirically observed individual behavior.

In the second, large part, the course begins with a brief introduction to Game theory and develops into the area of Bayesian games.  A few examples from the recent economic literature are studied in depth.</body>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: • To know deep functional dependencies between underlying individual preferences and empirically observed economic behaviour.
• To know main tools for the analysis of individual choice under uncertainty.
• To know main tools for the analysis of individual choice in the presence of strategic interaction.
• To know main tools for the analysis of individual choice in the presence of private information.
• To be able to formulate the problem of recovering preferences from behavior, and to solve its simple instances.
• To be able to apply Expected Utility theory for choices under uncertainty.
• To be able to compute different kinds of equilibria for different types of games.
• In general, to be able to use mathematical tools for relating behavior to the underlying economic model.

column1: <body>This Mathematics course presents the necessary Mathematical tools for analysing quantitative models that emerge from a variety of business and economic problems. The selection below reflects the scope of the studied Mathematical topics that will be useful for the analysis of economics and business problems. These topics are:

column2: • Functions and equations of one and two variables
• Sequences and series
• Financial applications
• Differentiation and optimization
• Integration
• Differential equations

column1: This course lays the foundation for the quantitative courses to follow in the IBA curriculum. The scientific description and analysis of complex practical business situations often requires an analytic approach. What is usually needed is the explicit description of the transition of a system when it moves from one state to the next. Mathematics is well equipped to assist in the difficult task of describing the essential elements of such transitions. The word ""model"" is often used for the quantitative description of the specific problem in which a system finds itself at any moment in time. Working with models is a recurring activity in business studies. The process of building and analysing business models requires a Mathematical way of thinking. Therefore Mathematical skills are essential for successfully handling these business models.

IMPORTANT NOTICE: The concepts, skills, and methods from the ‘Preparation course mathematics’ are a prerequisite for this course. You will not be able to understand the course without having successfully mastered the learning goals of the preparation course.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After completing this course, students will be able to apply the mathematical techniques covered in this course and to build, analyze and solve mathematical models emerging from business problems using mathematical techniques from the course and interpret the solutions in terms of the original problem. A detailed list of learning goals per learning unit is available in the document ‘Material overview’ in the ‘Course Information’ on Canvas.

column1: Traditionally, HTA researchers and health economists have concentrated on health outcomes expressed in QALYs when attempting to measure the benefits from health care products or programs. Traditionally, HTA researchers and health economists have concentrated on health outcomes expressed in QALYs when attempting to measure the benefits from health care products or programs. There is growing recognition, however, that patient preferences for health care products and programs are also shaped by non-health outcomes (such as amount of information) and process attributes (such as treatment location, or route of drug administration). Studies into these outcomes beyond health are an emerging trend in HTA and health economics. Discrete choice experiments (DCEs) are typically used for this purpose. DCE allows investigation of many types of research questions, as it is an attribute-based measure of benefit, which gives this method the flexibility to include any concern deemed of relevance. This course provides a resource for students in the health sector who want to familiarize themselves with assessment of patient preferences using DCEs. We present the fundamental principles and theory underlying DCEs, demonstrate the process of carrying out a choice study, and discuss the policy implications of the results.

Course materials will be studied in lectures and work groups, but students will also be actively involved in a DCE study with the aim to increase understanding of what is taught more quickly. Small groups will carry out a DCE study on a topic that is theirs to choose. Part of the work will be done during the work groups, and feedback will be provided continuously. The groups complete their work step by step over several weeks. The group's work will be evaluated on the basis of a short report about the DCE; individual members of the group may receive different grades based on their contributions.
The written examination is 70% of the final grade (minimum grade 5.0 or higher). The remainder derives from the group project (30%).
The re-sit is composed as a written examination (70%) and a group project (30%).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing the course, students will be able to:

column2: • recognize the importance of patient preference measurements in health care
• describe the theoretical foundation(s) of discrete choice experiments (DCEs)
• develop their own DCE using state-of-the-art (publishable) methods
• understand recent articles in the DCE literature and assess the validity of the presented conclusions
