column1: <body>Many individuals use many forms of media for many hours every day of their lives. In this course, we examine the different appropriation and interpretation of media that can be observed in different media audiences and their uses and influence of media on daily life. The course will present different schools of thought that study audiences and potential effects of media, such as: symbolic interactionism; uses and gratifications; media effects, critical and cultural studies; and relational perspectives of communication. Examples we will study include: social media, fandoms, newsmedia, propaganda, gender and sexuality, violence in media, and videogames, among others. In addition to reading contemporary communication and media research and contributing to class discussions, students have weekly assignments to ensure all the students prepared and reflected on theories and findings. A final individual assignment will require the student to write a critical essay analyzing a media product and its audiences according to the concepts learned in class.</body>

This seminar addresses the theory and practice of media campaigns as well as processes that drive the planning and execution of these campaigns and the role of the latest technological advancements in campaigning. Students will review theories and research on segmentation, media use and persuasion and will analyze real-world media campaigns by drawing on the theoretical and research articles covered in the course.

column1: In media studies, research tends to focus on the output of media industries. In this course, we take another perspective by investigating the strategic behavior of media firms that lies behind the media products we use. How did Facebook come to dominate the social media market? And how are incumbent TV broadcasters responding to the challenges posed by Youtube and Netflix? In order to study these and other questions, we will first address the particular characteristics of media products. For instance, media products often operate in dual product markets (advertisers and users), are

experience and cultural goods,-and often have zero marginal costs. In addition, media products are subject to fast-paced technological changes, globalization and great societal (e.g. political) pressures.

In order to study how market pressures and the nature of media products are impacting strategic behavior of media firms we will discuss and apply media management literature. We will take an explicit international perspective, using case studies from many different parts of the world. In these case studies, we will study how the specific economic characteristics of the media product and societal context within it is offered, affected the strategic management decisions that were made.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Major theoretical perspectives and key concepts in media economics.
• Current perspectives on the strategic management of media companies and the impact of external pressures (market, regulation, globalization etc.) on media firms' strategies.
• Analyze media products, media firms and media markets from an economic for-profit perspective.
• Take an international perspective on media economic research.
• Conduct case study research on media products.
• Formulate the implications of media economic analyses for strategic management decisions of media firms.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87157,2019,Media Entertainment Fans & Franchises,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. SMR Driessen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Most of us participate with media entertainment on an everyday basis. We watch movies via Netflix or stream music via Spotify. Some move beyond mere engagement and ‘invest’ greatly in their objects of affection (e.g. movies or musicians), e.g. by maintaining social media-accounts, or writing fan fiction. We can define such audience members as fans: the most passionate, but also the most critical consumers of media entertainment products.

In this seminar we explore this high level of participation in and with different media franchises, e.g. Netflix, Marvel’s superhero universe, Harry Potter, K-pop, American Idol, or influencers. Moreover, we will focus on topics like understanding (transcultural) fandom, produsing, fan tourism, crowdfunding, and storytelling. By looking at these different international franchises and their markets, we can discuss questions like: Why and how do fans engage with media entertainment franchises? How do the role and activities of fandoms change in the expanding world of media entertainment franchises? And, what are the (fan related-marketing) strategies of these franchises?
Every week different we’ll discussed different aspects of fandoms and franchises, applied to various forms of media entertainment like music, games, and movies.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key concepts and approaches in theory and research on media entertainment, particular fandom and media franchises.
• The relation between media entertainment, fandoms and franchises.
• Critically assess and compare existing theories on media entertainment, fan cultures and media franchises.
• Analyze and reflect upon popular cultural forms using concepts and theories covered in this course.
• Coherently present the discussed themes verbally (and visually) as well as in written assignments.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87216,2019,Media Entrepreneurship,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. S Horst'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The phenomenon of entrepreneurship is closely connected with a growing mediatization of organizations and society. In this way, media facilitate various creative processes and enables individuals and organizations to develop new ideas, facilitate new processes and build new ventures. At the same time, media entrepreneurship is a very young, but rapidly growing research area with a variety of backgrounds, concepts and methodological opportunities.

Therefore, the aims of this course are threefold. First, we aim to provide an overview of the field of media entrepreneurship and intend to spark critical investigations and shared discussions around its meaning. What is media entrepreneurship? What kind of styles, habits and practices can we see in different empirical settings? Second, we will explore current practices of entrepreneurship in the media and creative industries. How can we use media in creative manner to generate new opportunities and create sustainable organizational responses to the challenges we face? Third: These questions will be explored dialogically and creatively around different empirical phenomena in media entrepreneurship, for example through small research activities such as conducting market research or qualitative interviews with practitioners and analyzing these in class for further reflection.

This course introduces students to the major theoretical approaches in the study of mass mediated communication, drawing on research examples that cover various media (e.g. radio, television, film, newspapers, magazines, and the internet) and different countries. The course provides a historical and critical overview of theory and research on processes of media production, media contents, and media reception. The impact media have on culture and society is explored as well as debates that circulate about the media and media influences.
Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussion of student assignments and coursework.</body>

column1: Media industries have experienced radical changes in recent years as a result of new digital technologies and distribution platforms (e.g. gaming, the internet, mobile platforms etc.). For companies, workers and policymakers operating within media industries, these changes have severely impacted their operations: previously separated media markets have converged, new media products and business models have been developed, and users are no longer passive consumers but are actively peer producing content (so called user generated content). This seemingly chaotic period media industries find themselves in is the starting point of this course.

During the course, students will familiarize themselves with the latest trends and developments in the media industries. We will start with theoretical foundations that are crucial for understanding and researching media industries and media innovation. We will then turn our attention to trends in the media industries, and discuss how these trends impact the strategic behavior of industry actors (companies, audiences, policymakers). In addition to discussing literature, we will also use guest lectures and online material (e.g. videos) to discuss trends and strategies within the media sector.

column2: • The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

column1: Governments have always had a special interest in media markets. These interests derive from societal expectations that countries have of their media sector. These expectations can have political, socio-cultural and economic dimensions. The fast-paced changes in the media industry has forced governments around the world to reassess their media policy. For instance, the scandal around Cambridge Analytica’s usage of Facebook users’ data has forced many governments to rethink their privacy regulations. Although it lobbied actively against it, the new EU legalization on privacy that went into effect on the 25th of May 2018 and gives users more control over the usage of their personal data, is now being used by Facebook to improve their privacy policies, also outside of the EU.

Needless to say that governmental policy can have a great impact on media markets. During this course, we will use models from media economic scholars and institutional economics to conceptualize the interplay between government policy and media markets. In addition, we will focus on theories and developments around policy and regulation that allows us to analyze, critically assess and contextualize media policy.

This seminar connects relevant issues within media policy to relevant theoretical concepts. For instance, in all Western countries a debate is raging on fake news, freedom of speech and the right to privacy. In Asia, we see several governments taking an active role in shaping the digital environment, such as China’s Digital Wall policy that closes off Chinese audiences from unwanted media content and services.  We will discuss these and other developments in media policy using practical and international examples. Furthermore, we will try to formulate alternative policy options that governments could have taken.
The seminar is participative in nature, which means that students are required to prepare the lecture, participate in discussions and debat and give presentations.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

• global differences in media policy traditions

• analyse and critically evaluate different policy options
• assess the impact of governmental policy on media markets

column1: A decade ago, a travel agent was a legitimate job. Today, this line of employment has become redundant with online sites such as kayak, priceline and expedia allowing customers to shop virtually for competitive pricing. This captures not just a shift in the nature of employment, but possibly the birth of a new worldview, corporate ideology, management, and customer relations strategy in the tourism sector where certain intermediaries have become digital. In fact, change seems to be occurring across different industries with the advent of new media: we use mobile phones to check-in at airports through SMS barcodes; customers willingly watch ads in exchange for free television shows offered online by media companies; cancer patients verify treatment choices through online support groups; prostitutes use online platforms to increase their revenue. These shifts are however not necessarily unprecedented in the business world. If we look back, older information and communication media such as the print, radio and television have played a part in the shaping of diverse business models. Additionally, it is worth considering to what extent media transforms the business culture in its varied dimensions - legal, socio-cultural, economic and political. Also, how are companies’ online business presence syncing with their brick-and-mortar entities? Thereby, this course serves to create a historical and cultural overview of the role of information and communication media in the business sector and the opportunity to critically assess claims on radical shifts in organizational work practices and spaces. This includes a reexamining of the dichotomy between online and offline business in our current digitally-mediated environments. To do so, we look closely at the complex relations between the state, the market and the public.

To best situate such overarching understandings of the relations between business and media, this course applies theory to real world business news, trends, and events concerning social media and the internet. Emphasis will be placed on emerging markets and their usage of media to restructure their role in the global economy. Overall, the intent of this course is to gain a more critical and global perspective on the role of media in the shaping of businesses across cultures, histories and contexts.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 45.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Advertising, materialism, and consumption are central aspects of modern societies across the globe. Contemporary societies are intertwined with consumer culture and marked by peoples continuously growing wants and needs, as well as the conspicuous consumption of mass produced and marketed goods. This course provides a psycho-cultural perspective on consumer culture, and advertising and branded space in particular. We examine the history of advertising, the commercial and social aspects of the messages conveyed by ads, and the advertising industry's influence on social relations and institutions such as politics. Furthermore, we discuss the various ways in marketing to classify consumers, such as the Values and Lifestyle Typology – and learn that individuals differ greatly in their (susceptibility to) consumer values.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 50. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
· Current theoretical perspectives and research methods in the field of consumer culture
· The history and commercial and social aspects of advertising
· Integrate knowledge gained from specific topics and integrate this in a focus written report
· Apply a psycho-cultural perspective on consumer culture, and critically reflect on the advertising industry’s influence on society
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86331,2019,Media and Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. RFI Moody', 'prof.dr. EH Klijn']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Complex governance processes in networks are constantly influenced by the outside world. This is especially happening through the media attention and the dynamics this generates in networks. Media have become a separate institution with its own logic (the media logic) and its own rules how to bring news and package it. Media logic is concerned with the content of the news provided as well as the formats in which news is created and processed. The format of an item on the television news bulletin for instance, has to meet certain criteria: the slot allocated for the story is only a few minutes long, it has to have news value and it should attract or keep the attention of the viewers. These criteria influence how reality is constructed in the news story.

column3: Many authors claim that media have profound influence on our daily social life, how policy problems are shaped and on various other institutions in society. And this becomes visible when media pay attention to governance processes. Not only does the visibility of these processes enhance but also the decision dynamics change considerably as agenda forming theories have been arguing for some time.

The mediatized world asks for public leaders who can communicate their messages in clear “sound bites,” who can adapt swiftly to new developments and “media hypes,” and who can create attractive brands which arouse positive associations with citizens and voters. But in this public leaders in modern network society are faced with a growing gap between the front stage of a mediatized political world on the one hand and the daily practical life of complexity of governance processes in networks on the other hand (the backstage).

In this course we explore the media as a separate institution, their influence on policy processes and the requirements it posed on public managers. But we also explore managerial strategies that public managers have to influence media attention, like (political) public relations, and public branding.

column2: </body>

column1: Migration has been a characteristic of societies for centuries. Humans have always migrated to search for better economic conditions and employment, to escape from war, conflicts or hunger, to flee from political persecution and religious intolerance to name a few. In recent years,     however, continuing immigration flows and increasing diversity in Europe and elsewhere have led   to more complex processes of integration and the emergence of the so-called transnationalism, a phenomenon characterized by cross-border engagements of migrants, organizations and institutions, as well as the multiple embeddings of migrants in their host and origin places. In this course, we will focus on the critical role played by media  and communication in the different levels of the transnational condition of migration, ranging from mass media representations of migrants and refugees to the mediated communication exchanges conducted in the social media scenarios, from political negotiation between relevant actors in the field of policy-making through the political and economic side of migrants’ lives to the role played by hands-on intercultural mediation projects.

The purpose of this course is to provide a platform for students to develop their own approach to a better understanding of the intricate relationships between media and migration across different sociopolitical and cultural contexts (European and non-European) and types of migration (e.g. economic migrants, second-generation migrants, expats, refugees, asylum migrants, etc.). In eight weeks, students will work on their own (applied) research project that includes topics related to media, communication and (transnational) migration processes. The students’ commitment to carry out such a joint endeavour will entail a further commitment to investigating migration and transnational contexts, using theories and empirical analyses in their argument, contacting relevant migration actors, practicing intercultural skills training for conducting research and/or working in this field, exploring the potential of stakeholders, among others. Furthermore, these sessions will help students gain conceptual, empirical and practical skills and knowledge for the development of their master thesis projects in this field. This knowledge will be further applied in the weekly workshops through in-class activities and theoretical and practical assignments.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The workshop Media and Migration is oriented towards MA students who are interested in developing both theoretical and practical (applied) projects in the field of media and migration, and intercultural communication. This course aims to offer conceptual, empirical and practical tools for building students’ knowledge about current (research) topics and trends in this interdisciplinary field that can also be used in the development of students' master thesis projects.
Upon completion of this course the students will be able to:

column2: • understand the key theories and concepts (acculturation, identities, social capital, media affordances, digital divide, media framing, etc.) and methodologies (qualitative and quantitative approaches) used in research on the relationships between media, migration and intercultural communication in a transnational context (content).
• apply their knowledge to the production of their online project and Master thesis proposal at a later stage of the MA programme (content and performance).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87117,2019,Media and Politics,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. DD Dumitrica'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course analyzes the close and multifaceted relationship between media and politics. It is largely through the media that citizens develop an idea of what the world of politics looks like and how it operates. All media are influential in this respect: not just broadcast news, newspapers, and current event magazines, but also (fictional) films and novels, and, increasingly, blogs and social media. Traditional media enable politicians, government officials, and other political actors to simultaneously reach millions of people. New technologies, in turn, intensify the possibilities of citizens themselves to engage politically with one another and to directly challenge politicians and authorities. Fictional media, finally, play an important role in letting us re-live, criticize and imagine politics beyond our everyday experiences. With this encompassing view of the relationship between media and politics in mind, we will pay special attention to politicians, journalists, and citizens/audiences, their interactions and the ways in which these interactions impact democracy. We will discuss different strategies through which politicianslike public figures in generaltry to turn the media into their allies, even at the expense of compromising their politics to become more mediagenic. We will also analyze journalistic practices and products and approach them as responses to sometimes diverging interests, including those of politicians, audiences, and media organizations. Finally, we will ponder on political communication's alleged contributions to citizens' re- and/or de-politicization.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Key normative claims about the media in democratic societies.
• The relationships between media institutions and political institutions in international perspective.
• The roles of political reporters and other media professionals, politicians, and citizens in political communication processes.
• The forces and processes that shape political media content in specific ways.
• The effects of media coverage on citizen political attitudes and behavior, as well as the possibilities of citizens in shaping these effects.
• Recognize and articulate political communication concepts as they relate to different media content they encounter.
• Read, critique, and apply major political communication concepts to questions about media and society.
• Build arguments that synthesize and integrate knowledge about the relationship between media and politics.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87189,2019,Media and Social-Cultural Change,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. I Awad Cherit'],,"Inhoud

column1: The idea that the media (can) have the power to change society and culture is at least as old as propaganda and censorship. And yet, questions about the relationship between media and socio- cultural change continue to be at the core of much communication and media research today. How does this relationship look like? (When) Do the media simply reflect social-change? (When) Can they also facilitate change or even determine it? Do certain media genres, platforms, or media production models lend themselves to more conservative or revolutionary goals than others? What roles do people—activists, producers, and members of the audience, for example—play in this? How has the power of the media changed, especially in the last decades and with new technologies?

This course uncovers the complexities behind these questions and explores answers offered in the academic literature, as well as the practical experiences and views of individuals who work in the media and in the promotion of social change. In order to interpret and assess these answers, experiences and views we rely on theories from communication and media studies, as well as social theory more generally. We pay special attention, for example, to ideology and hegemony, to (journalistic) objectivity, mediatization, media/technological determinism, and agency. Since the relationship between the media and socio- cultural change is not only complicated, but also fluid and context-specific, the course adopts a historical and cross-national perspective. Course activities include group presentations, active participation in the course blog, interviews with practitioners, and a final essay.

column1: In deze module staat ondernemerschap in de mediasector in het algemeen en in de journalistiek in het bijzonder centraal. We kijken naar bestaande en nieuwe businessmodellen, van zowel grote bedrijven, van jonge startups als van individuele professionals. Tijdens de module lezen studenten literatuur over deze businessmodellen, verdiepen zich in onderzoek op dit terrein en gaan in discussie met gastsprekers over inzichten uit de praktijk. Thema’s als platformisering freelance journalistiek, content marketing en crowdfunding passeren de revue. De module heeft als doel inzichten uit de theorie te verbinden met de actuele praktijk. Via deze weg leren we over de mogelijkheden en beperkingen van verschillende businessmodellen voor bedrijven en professionals. Tevens komen de maatschappelijke implicaties van deze businessmodellen aan bod, zoals de toenemende vervaging van grenzen tussen journalistiek, amusement, voorlichting en PR.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Studenten hebben kennis van en inzicht in:

column2: • Businessmodellen in de mediasector;
• Onderzoek naar ondernemerschap in de mediasector;
• Actuele voorbeelden van ondernemerschap in de mediasector.
• De verschillen tussen theoretische en praktische kennis op dit terrein;
• De mogelijkheden en beperkingen van verschillende businessmodellen;
• De maatschappelijke implicaties van deze businessmodellen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course will examine key issues across Latin American Media. It strives to provide with a panorama of what is happening across the continent and examine the role of media in politics, and its relationship to national identity and state building. The sessions will discuss on a country basis; the build-up of national media production and the flow of media, into, across and out of Latin America; as well as the evolution of key genres, like the telenovela, that have come to be identified with Latin America. Theoretically, we will examine approaches that have originated in Latin America: hybridity, dependency, imperialism, globalization, as well as, the development of geo-cultural and cultural- linguistic regions. An element of this course will include watching and discussing media from the region, as well as evaluations made in and outside the region. Specialists from different areas of the region will provide lectures in order to explore more closely the link among the media formats, contents and the changing social realities in the Latin-American region.</body>

column1: This course focuses on children's media use and on parents and educators who raise their children to media-literate persons. The child's media-landscape will be discussed together with theories on how the media may influence children. Next the role of parents will be discussed. Parents can use various strategies to further positive media effects such as learning, or dampen negative effects such as fear reactions or aggression. Students will be stimulated to explore and think about their own experiences and ideas on the strategies that parents use with traditional media as television and  cinema movies, and with modern media such as computers, game consoles, smart phones, and tablets. Furthermore, we will look at tools that exist for parents, such as rating systems (Kijkwijzer and PEGI), technical safety applications on the computer, and several information and advice sources,  such as Common Sense Media. The final goal of this course is a to propose a practical tool for supporting parents in guiding their children’s media use.
Note: the course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Different academic perspectives on parents' mediation of their children’s media use.
• The contemporary children's media landscape.
• How and why parents guide their children's media consumption; parenting support tools, such as rating systems.
• Critically reflect upon different academic perspectives and theories on parental mediation.
• Independently apply these in their own writings and (desk)research.
• Present their ideas on parental mediation to an audience of fellow students.

column1: This course focuses on the key role of the media and cultural industries in the international spread of culture. Cultural exchange transcending regions and nation-states is not a new phenomenon, but the past three decades witnessed an accelerated intensification of international cultural flows. Among other reasons, this is a consequence of the introduction of new media technologies and the rise of multinational conglomerates in the media and cultural industries.

We will explore different theoretical approaches to examine the relationship between globalisation in the media and cultural industries, and the symbolic meaning of media products. Furthermore, during the weekly sessions of this course, we will discuss themes such as global cities, multiculturalism, global media events and cosmopolitanism.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key developments in the global spread of culture and the role of media therein.
• Different perspectives in the scholarly and public debate on the nature and impact of cultural globalisation.
• Apply relevant theoretical insights and methods in the analysis of globalisation processes and their social consequences.
• Critically reflect on academic texts, both verbal and in written form.
• Design and write an essay; make an academic argument.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87956,2019,Mediation advocacy: theory and practice,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. AJ de Roo', 'dr. RW Jagtenberg']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In Western society, law students are led to believe that in-court adjudication is the self-evident and thus normal method for settling disputes. This conception, however, is far away from everyday reality. Apart from the fact that many disputes do not lend themselves to authoritative yes-or-no decisions, disputants may experience a series of problems when they choose to assert their rights in court, such as costs, delays, proof proceedings, uncertainty and unpredictability. Where bilateral negotiations are deadlocked and the resourcefulness of a third party is sought, other methods of dispute settlement than adjudication are therefore increasingly considered by disputants, particularly in areas such as construction, employment and family disputes.

Mediation and other modes of dispute resolution such as conciliation, Med.Arb., mini trial, fact finding, all belong to the A(lternative) D(ispute) R(esolution)-family. These methods tend to focus on the parties’ real interests and their future relationships. Possible legal problems relating to ADR are discussed such as the compatibility of ADR with the Right of Access to Court, and the legal status of mediated settlements. In addition, national and European developments on court-annexed mediation shall be highlighted. In this context, the outcomes of inter alia the Dutch national mediation project shall be discussed. Practical training is provided through role plays and other practical exercises, which are essential for a proper and profound understanding of the working of mediation – definitely for those who pursue a career in law practice.
Over the last decades, mediation has become one of the typical services provided by law practitioners. Obviously, law graduates should be abreast of this development, which is here to stay.</body>

column2: <title></title>

column1: The aim of this course is to give the participating student an understanding of the wide variety of dispute settlement processes, with an emphasis on mediation advocacy. After completion of the course the student should be able to distinguish the various modes of dispute resolution, in particular from the perspective of a lawyer assisting client-disputants.
The student shall be assessed on area related knowledge and analytical skills.</body>

column2: <title></title>

column1: <body>Mediation topics include: 1) simple mediation with any type of independent and dependent variables (i.e., continuous, dichotomous, multicategorical), 2) mediation with multiple parallel mediators, 3) mediation with multiple serial mediators. Moderation topics include: 1) moderation models with up to 2 moderators (3-way interactions) using any type of independent and dependent variables, 2) analysis of unconditional versus conditional effects, 3) Model estimation and interpretation, 4) Visualization. I will also discuss how to analyze conditional process models (i.e., models that include both mediation and moderation). Depending on the pace of the course I will also try to cover some specialized topics such as mediation analysis in within-participants designs and mediation analysis using a binary mediator. The course will be focused on teaching you how to conduct the appropriate analysis and interpret your results. We will be using PROCESS (Hayes, 2013) for the purposes of this course. Attendants should have a recent version of SPSS and PROCESS installed on their computer.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In this course you will learn how to conduct and interpret the results of mediation, moderation, and conditional process analyses. Mediation describes the case where an independent variable X influences another variable M (mediator), which in turn influences the dependent variable Y. For example, giving time to others (X) has been shown to enhance one’s own feelings of competence (M), which in turn leads to the feeling that one has more time available (Y), (Mogilner, Chance, and Norton 2012). Moderation describes the case where the effect of the independent variable X on the dependent variable Y changes across different levels of another variable M (moderator). For instance, perceived conflict between goals (X) makes consumers feel that they have less time available (Y) and this effect is further moderated by breathing speed (M). When consumers are nudged to breathe slowly the negative effect of perceived goal conflict on feelings of time is reduced (Etkin, Evangelidis, and Aaker 2015). Conditional process models combine mediation with moderation.

This is an applied course: knowledge of algebra is not required. However, a basic understanding of OLS regression is necessary. This course is targeted to any person doing social science research that wants to learn how to test for mediation and moderation in his or her data.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/84159,2019,Medical Demography (HS04),Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['dr. J.A. Haagsma', 'dr. W.J. Nusselder', 'prof. dr. F.J. van Lenthe']",,

<body>Is euthanasia of demented patients in a progressed state morally permissible? When should doctors refuse requests for new technologies of assisted reproduction, such as in vitro fertilisation (IVF)? Do we have a moral duty to fund orphan drugs? What should government, industry and individuals do in order to tackle problems like obesity or organ donation? Are new technologies to enhance the capabilities of human beings (such as cognition, social behaviour and mood, or physical appearance) morally desirable? Are patients with diverse cultural and ethnical background treated equally in the clinic?  Medical ethics and public health ethics are interesting and complex fields of study. In this course, we study pressing ethical issues and how theoretical approaches, concepts and methods may help us to deal with these issues. In the first part of the course, the most important theoretical approaches (utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue ethics) and concepts in ethics and medical ethics (e.g. autonomy, paternalism, informed consent) will be introduced. In the second part of the course, the obtained knowledge will be applied to issues in medicine and public health care and critically reflect on central arguments including the influence of hidden assumptions and technological developments.</body>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

In this module we study pressing ethical issues and how theoretical approaches, concepts and methods may help us to deal with these issues. The first couple of meetings are devoted to the most important theoretical approaches (utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue ethics) and concepts in ethics and medical ethics (e.g. autonomy, paternalism, informed consent). Next, we will focus on issues in medicine and public health care and critically reflect on central arguments including the influence of hidden assumptions and technological developments.

analyse, criticize and relate core concepts (e.g. autonomy, competence, informed consent, paternalism, justice, responsibility for health etc) to practical debates;
to explain how (anthropological) assumptions play a role in the moral debate;
argue for particular points of view in concrete problem cases and to acknowledge the strength and weakness of relevant arguments;
evaluate their own ethical beliefs and justify their recommended courses of action.

column1: This course deals with the vast and important area of memory. Memory forms the basis for much of human cognition and behavior. We use our memory not only to remember the groceries we have to buy at the supermarket or to remember where and when to meet a friend, we also need our memory to engage in a conversation, to make calculations, to recognize loved ones, and even to ski downhill. In other words, memory plays an essential role in our daily lives. This becomes even more evident when we consider patients who have severe memory disorders caused by an accident or disease.
The course addresses cognitive and biological aspects of human memory. The following topics will be discussed.
The Neural Basis of Memory and Memory Disorders

column2: <title></title>

column1: <div>This course has the following learning objectives:

column2: • At the end of the course students have intermediate knowledge of the most important empirical findings and theories of short-term/working memory.
• At the end of the course students have intermediate knowledge of the most important empirical findings and theories of long-term memory (including semantic and implicit memory tasks).
• At the end of the course students have a basic understanding of some important mathematical models of human memory.
• At the end of the course students have basic knowledge of the biological basis of human memory.
• At the end of the course students are able to critically evaluate journal articles.

column2: <title></title>

column1: In deze module wordt de scheiding van het denken over markt en moraliteit ter sprake gebracht, die groeide toen in de (neo)klassieke economie de homo economicus als werkhypothese werd gepostuleerd. Enerzijds komen hier studies aan de orde van economen uit de klassiek en neoklassieke school (Lionel Robbins, Milton Friedman, Paul Samuelson) waarin reflecties op de wisselwerking tussen markt en moraliteit uit beeld raken en er van uitgegaan wordt dat de enige verantwoordelijkheid van een bedrijf het maken van winst is. Anderzijds komen werken ter sprake waarin - in het verlengde van Smiths Wealth of Nations en Theory of Moral Sentiments  - aandacht wordt besteed aan de doorwerking van deugden als moed, zelfbeheersing, rechtvaardigheid, wijsheid en welwillendheid in de markt.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Het bieden van een overzicht van standaardwerken na Adam Smith, waarin steeds meer sprake is van een loskoppeling van de intrinsieke link tussen de marktwerking en moraliteit op grond van de ontwikkeling van het concept van de homo economicus.

Een eerste kennismaking met de katholieke sociale leer en de protestantse doctrines over markt en marktwerking voor zover hier de wisselwerking tussen drijfveren, marktwerking en de rechtvaardige maatschappij aan de orde is gesteld.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87257,2019,Mensenrechten in een pluriforme samenleving,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['prof.dr. KAM Henrard, LLM']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De minor ‘Mensenrechten in een pluriforme samenleving’ is zeer geschikt voor studenten die interesse hebben in de fundamentele rechten van de mens. In deze minor worden verschillende mensenrechten behandeld en wordt bekeken wat de rol van deze mensenrechten in een pluriforme samenleving is. Onderwerpen als recht op gelijke behandeling, godsdienstvrijheid, vrijheid van meningsuiting, recht op onderwijs, gelijke toegang tot tewerkstelling en publieke diensten komen tijdens deze minor aan bod, met bijzonder aandacht voor de positie van minderheden (inclusief migranten), van LGBT, en vrouwen. Daarnaast wordt in het onderwijs aandacht besteed aan (actuele) maatschappelijke vraagstukken op deze terreinen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Deze minor verrijkt het (dominante) juridische perspectief over mensenrechten en hun rol binnen een pluriforme samenleving, met een sociaal-wetenschappelijk perspectief. Het volgen van deze minor stelt je in staat om problemen rond de multiculturele en pluriforme samenleving te identificeren, te benoemen in termen van (bepaalde) mensenrechten en eventuele botsingen tussen mensenrechten te analyseren vanuit dit dubbele perspectief.

column1: Het Eerstejaars Mentor Programma “Bedrijfskunde: haal eruit wat er in zit” is speciaal ontworpen om de overstap van de middelbare school naar de universiteit makkelijker te maken. Het programma is geen traditionele cursus. Alle sessies worden door een tweedejaars bedrijfskunde student gegeven. Studenten dus die zelf een succesvolle overstap naar de universiteit hebben gemaakt en vanuit hun eigen ervaring nieuwe studenten willen ondersteunen.

Tijdens de sessies heb je de mogelijkheid om medestudenten te leren kennen en ervaringen en informatie uit te wisselen over het navigeren van je nieuwe omgeving. Immers de universiteit is niet vergelijkbaar met de middelbare school en er wordt veel meer zelfstandigheid van je verwacht. In dit programma leer je welke middelen je ter beschikking hebt om je in dit proces te ondersteunen en hoe je deze middelen optimaal kunt benutten. Daarnaast help het Mentor Programma je om deel te worden van de BA gemeenschap.
De cursus bestaat uit 9 sessies met je mentorgroep en begint op de eerste dag van je studie en eindigt aan het begin van blok 3. Daarnaast heb je 2 individuele koffiemomenten met je mentor.
Meer informatie over het rooster kun je vinden op My Timetable.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86779,2019,Mentor Programme,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. VR Ohms'],,"Inhoud

column1: The First Year Mentor Programme: Making IBA Work For You is both an opportunity and resource for incoming IBA Students. The BAP-MG Mentor Programme was developed to support first year students as they make their adjustment to university life in the international setting offered by IBA. This programme is not a course in the traditional sense.

The sessions are led by second year IBA students, all of whom have participated in the Mentor Programme last year, and who have decided they want to pass on their experience and knowledge to incoming students.

During the sessions, you will have the opportunity to meet with fellow students, to share experience and knowledge about ways to navigate the classroom setting and information that is offered to you, to adjust to student life in Rotterdam and get tips about how to best make use of the resources available to you. In addition, the Mentor Programme serves as a bridge to help you adjust to the IBA culture and become part of the larger IBA community. Your mentor and fellow students can all serve as resources so that you can truly make the best of IBA.

The course consists of 10 sessions with your mentor group, beginning the first week of studies and ending at the beginning of block 3. In addition to these group sessions, you will also have 2 individual coffee moments with your mentor. Detailed info about your workshop schedule can be found on My Timetable.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Module A: Academische studievaardigheden in blok 1, 2 en 3. Academische studievaardigheden beoogt studenten een goede start van hun studie te bieden. Daarnaast biedt Academische studievaardigheden begeleiding in het kader van het Bindend Studie Advies (BSA). Elke mentorgroep bestaat uit maximaal vijftien studenten, die begeleid worden door een vaste mentor (een ouderejaarsstudent). Tijdens plenaire bijeenkomsten ontvangen de studenten informatie over het studeren aan de ESE en worden effectieve studiemethoden besproken. Daarnaast heeft elke student drie individuele gesprekken met de mentor om zijn of haar studieresultaten te bespreken.

• Module B: Academische presentatievaardigheden. Deze module vindt plaats in blok 2. Studenten werken met een online applicatie om hun presentatievaardigheden te oefenen. Daarnaast moeten de studenten enkele opdrachten uitvoeren en een presentatie geven.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87421,2019,Mergers & acquisitions and corporate governance,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. S Vanhaverbeke'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course students learn to evaluate firms’ corporate governance and control mechanisms, understand how such mechanisms affect firm value, and understand how mergers and acquisitions can help to improve governance and hence enhance firm value. One part of the course provides an overview of (international) mechanisms of corporate governance and how they work. A second part of the course discusses one important way of changing governance and control (corporate restructuring): mergers and acquisitions. Mergers and acquisitions are transactions that define the future of a firm. Diligently managing mergers and acquisitions is therefore of key concern to executives. This involves more than analysis and valuation. It involves organizing an M&A process, selecting investment banks, financing a transaction, legal documentation, due diligence, negotiating, defense strategies, communication, and post-merger integration. In this course we will address these aspects of the M&A process. In the course, CFOs, bankers, consultants and other M&A professionals, share their experiences as our guests in class. They will discuss best practices and reflect upon the link with M&A theory.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students are able to:

column2: • Understand the pros and cons of various (international) corporate governance mechanisms;
• Design a corporate governance and control structure;
• Develop an acquisition plan for an M&A transaction;
• Understand the challenges M&A professionals are faced with when executing transactions;
• Link the implementation issues that are discussed in the class room with M&A theory;
• Discuss and conclude in teams multiple viewpoints on a particular M&A case, and present and defend the joint findings in a class setting.

column1: body { font-size: 9pt;A world. Specifically, you should be able to answer questions such as: Overall, do M&As pay? What are the various motivations for M&As? When do M&As make sense? What are the drivers of M&A waves? How does one value a M&A deal? What is the M&A process? What is the appropriate M&A risk management strategy? What does it take to make the ""synergy"" come to life? When do leveraged buy-outs make sense, and how can they be financed? etc.

The general objectives are that 1) although you may know nothing about M&A before taking the course, after taking the course you will have a broad and solid understanding of all important aspects of M&A, and 2) after taking the course you will have good knowledge of how M&A works from both theoretical and practical perspectives, and will be able to act as an analyst and analyze/evaluate/solve a real-world M&A transaction.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87432,2019,Mergers and acquisitions,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. A Rajamani'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course is intended to enhance the M&A preparedness of students in their future roles (M&A advisor/employee/stakeholder) by providing an overview of the major economic and accounting challenges associated with M&As. The first module of the course will focus on the various rational and (sub-rational) motives/drivers of mergers (or takeovers), the sources of value creation and the determinants of payment/financing choices. The second module will discuss some of the important accounting challenges and re-visit valuation techniques in the context of M&A. The final module will focus on the acquisition of distressed firms as well as the drivers of various types of restructuring activities.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After taking this course students should be able to:
(i) Understand the drivers of M&A transactions and the implications of different M&A strategies for firms’ stakeholders,
(ii) Be able to assess a deal from the target/acquiring shareholders’ perspective given the deal terms;
(iii) Be able to apply appropriate valuation techniques for valuing a potential targets and structuring deal terms,
(iv) Have an overview of academic evidence relating to different aspects of M&A.</body>

column1: This course examines framing theory and discusses its relevance for media and communication studies. During interactive seminars, critical discussions on framing are followed by workshops in which students work on practical challenges in message framing and persuasion. The course assessment consists of two parts: an individual assignment in which the students write an essay on the topic of their own choice and a group assignment in which groups of four to five students select one of the scenarios offered by the lecturer and prepares a PR conference. While, the individual assignment tests theoretical knowledge, the group assignment tests practical knowledge. In both assignments, critical reflection is expected.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

• Deal with case studies and prepare persuasive messages in clear and purposeful way while keeping the context and the audience in mind.
• Organize a creative and successful press conference.
• Collaborate in a divers project team
• Critically reflect on past organizations and learn from experience.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89543,2019,Metaphysics in Spinoza and Leibniz: Original Motivations and Contemporary Legacy,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. JA van Ruler'],,Inhoud

column2: <title></title>

column1: Attendance is obligatory. Extra assignments will be given to those not attending more than one seminar.

n this Master Course, we shall delve into a detailed analysis of Spinoza’s and Leibniz’ metaphysics, asking ourselves to what extent these historical positions were intended to solve early-modern philosophical dilemma’s and/or to contribute to meeting seventeenth-century moral and theological demands. While both Spinoza and Leibniz reintroduced a metaphysical notion of formal causation and ontologically founded types of essentialism, and thereby reversed René Descartes’ earlier attempts to dispose of such metaphysical notions, they are nevertheless praised in continental philosophy today for what is seen as their anti-essentialism. Contemporary thinkers consider Spinoza and Leibniz to present natural change as being guided not so much by determinate essences, but by the actual development of existing individuals. Their philosophies, in other words, are now being read as giving expression to the idea of creative activity and the fundamental mutability of things. In this course, three seminars will be devoted to Spinoza, three to Leibniz, and a final two to the reception of Spinoza and Leibniz in Giorgio Agamben and Gilles Deleuze.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>At the end of the course, students will be able to formulate a position of their own on the equitability and historical aptness of the appropriation of Spinozism and Leibnizian philosophy in contemporary continental thought on the basis of a thorough knowledge of Spinoza’s and Leibniz’ metaphysical systems and their historical context, as well as their present-day reception.</body>

<body>Het vak Inleiding methoden en technieken biedt een eerste kennismaking met de belangrijkste manieren van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek die in de criminologie worden gebruikt. Tijdens de onderwijsgroepen en de hoorcolleges wordt aandacht besteed aan onderwerpen en begrippen die van belang zijn om goed sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek te kunnen herkennen en zelf uit te kunnen voeren. Gedacht kan worden aan het formuleren van de probleemstelling, het bepalen van het onderzoeksontwerp (ook wel design genoemd), het kiezen van de methoden van data verzamelen, het operationaliseren van concepten, het kiezen van de technieken om de data te analyseren, de interpretatie van de bevindingen en het doen van uitspraken ten behoeve van de beantwoording van de probleemstelling. Zowel kwantitatief als kwalitatief onderzoek komen bij het vak aan de orde. Tijdens de practica gaan de studenten zelf oefenen met het uitvoeren van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek. Tijdens de kwantitatieve practica wordt met verschillende kwantitatieve analysetechnieken in SPSS geoefend. Ook zijn er kwalitatieve practicumbijeenkomsten waarin de studenten (in kleine groepen) zullen gaan oefenen met interviewvaardigheden.</body>

• de basisbegrippen van methoden en technieken van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek omschrijven en uitleggen;

• de kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve onderzoekscyclus beschrijven en uitleggen;
• uitleggen waarom en wanneer kwantitatief onderzoek en kwalitatief onderzoek wordt gebruikt binnen de criminologie;
• uitleggen wanneer je op basis van onderzoek generaliserende uitspraken kunt doen en bijbehorende kernbegrippen omschrijven en uitleggen;
• verschillende methoden van kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve dataverzameling herkennen en omschrijven;
• omschrijven en uitleggen wat beschrijvende analyse en verklarende analyse inhoudt;

<body>

column3: In dit tweede methodevak van de opleiding Criminologie wordt de kennis uit Inleiding methoden en technieken verdiept en worden meer toepassingen aangeleerd in het verzamelen en analyseren van kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve gegevens. Na afloop van dit vak is de student er klaar voor om zijn eerste eigen onderzoek te gaan uitvoeren.

In het kwantitatieve gedeelte van het vak ligt de focus op het analyseren van data. Na de beschrijvende analyses die in Inleiding methoden en technieken zijn behandeld worden nu methoden geleerd om (complexe) samenhang tussen variabelen te analyseren. Daarbij gaan we uitgebreid in op situaties waarbij meer dan twee kenmerken onderling samenhangen (multivariate analyse).

In het kwalitatieve gedeelte van het vak komen diverse nieuwe dataverzamelingsmethoden aan bod, namelijk het focus groep interview, online onderzoek, visuele etnografie en documentenanalyse. Vervolgens wordt geleerd hoe kwalitatieve onderzoekers hun gegevens analyseren. Tevens worden ethische problemen besproken en de manier waarop onderzoekers hun subjectieve persoonlijke veldwerk ervaringen kunnen aanwenden bij het beter begrijpen van het onderwerp dat ze onderzoeken.

column2: </body>
<title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Studenten zijn na dit vak in staat een gefundeerde keuze te maken uit dataverzameling en analysemethoden, voor exploratief, beschrijvend, verklarend en toetsend onderzoek. Daartoe hebben zij naast de kennis uit Inleiding methoden en technieken nu ook inzicht in de basiskenmerken en principes van vier kwalitatieve dataverzamelingsmethoden (focusgroep, kwalitatief online onderzoek, visuele etnografie en kwalitatieve documentanalyse) en van belangrijke bestaande kwantitatieve databronnen. Studenten kunnen bovendien de gegevens die voortkomen uit kwalitatief onderzoek coderen en analyseren en weten welke ethische problemen er kleven aan kwalitatief onderzoek.

Wat betreft kwantitatieve analysemethoden kunnen zij bivariate en multivariate analyses uitvoeren met variabelen van verschillende meetniveaus en de uitkomsten daarvan interpreteren en daarover rapporteren. Ook zijn studenten in staat methoden en resultatenbeschrijvingen in wetenschappelijke literatuur te begrijpen en kritisch na te gaan of de uitspraken die worden gedaan terecht zijn, gegeven de gebruikte onderzoeksmethoden.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85741,2019,Methoden van Forensisch Handelen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. FCP van der Horst'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit practicum gaan de studenten actief aan de slag met de praktische uitwerking van wat in het algemeen wordt gezien als de basis voor het handelen in het forensisch werkveld, namelijk het risicobeginsel, het behoeftebeginsel en het responsiviteitsbeginsel. Studenten leren (1) op basis van gevalideerde instrumenten het recidiverisico in te schatten, (2) hoe in behandeling te interveniëren op criminogene en niet-criminogene behoeften van een cliënt en (3) hoe om te gaan met niet-gemotiveerde cliënten en hoe motiverende gespreksvoering toe te passen in de forensische praktijk.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na afronding van dit practicum hebben studenten:

column2: • kennis van de in het forensisch werkveld veelgebruikte What works?-principes uit het Risk-Needs-Responsivity model (Bonta & Andrews, 2007; Ward & Stewart, 2003) en daarmee van de uitgangspunten voor effectieve diagnostiek en behandeling in een forensisch kader;;
• kennisgemaakt met de rol van risicotaxatie in het forensisch veld;
• kennisgemaakt met de rol van risicotaxatie in het forensisch veld;
• zicht op de behandeling van criminogene en niet-criminogene behoeften van cliënten en kennen zij het onderscheid tussen statische en dynamische risicofactoren;
• zich bewust van algemene werkzaamheid van interventies en de noodzaak in behandeling rekening te houden met specifieke eigenschappen van de cliënt in zijn specifieke context;;
• basisvaardigheden van motiverende gespreksvoering (Miller & Rollnick, 2012) onder de knie.

column1: De student is in staat om zonder instructie en met enige begeleiding (onderdeel schrijfonderwijs):

column2: • Een samenhangende en heldere rapportage te schrijven;
• Een professionele schrijfstijl toe te passen en deze af te stemmen op een specifieke doelgroep (e.g. kinderen, ouders, leerkrachten en andere professionals);
• Een casusbeschrijving conform NVO-richtlijnen betreffende de BAPD te schrijven.

column1: Dit vak verdiept de methodologische expertise die studenten in vooropleidingen of voorbereidingstrainingen hebben opgedaan. Hoewel het vak de basiselementen en toepasbaarheid van iedere methode bestrijkt, ligt de nadruk in het seminar op het eigen gebruik van onderzoeksmethoden door studenten, vooral in de eerste dataverzamel-fasen van het onderzoeksproces. Het vak draagt daarmee dus bij aan vaardigheden van studenten om zelfstandig onderzoek uit te voeren – vaardigen die nodig zijn in de research workshops en de MA thesis later in het programma. Vier typen onderzoeksmethoden worden besproken: de survey, het open interview, kwantitatieve en kwalitatieve inhoudsanalyse.
De modules worden verzorgd door diverse docenten elk met hun eigen onderzoeksspecialisatie. Het vak behandelt uiteenlopende thema’s, onderzoeksobjecten en mediatypen.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Studenten hebben kennis van en inzicht in:

column2: • Gangbare onderzoeksmethoden op het gebied van media en communicatie.
• Onderzoek op te zetten, meetinstrumenten en sampling strategieën (met betrekking tot specifieke methoden) te evalueren.
• De voornaamste verschillen in de manier waarop specifieke onderzoeksmethoden worden gebruikt en het soort data dat ze genereren.
• Hun eigen onderzoeksopzet, meetinstrumenten en sampling strategieën ten aanzien van concrete onderzoeksvragen over media-inhoud of mediagebruik te ontwikkelen.
• Bruikbare data te verzamelen.
• Op hun gebruik van verschillende onderzoeksmethoden te reflecteren.
• Met collega’s onderzoeksstrategieën te bediscussiëren, te ontwikkelen en te beoordelen.

<body>Tijdens dit vak wordt aan de hand van een aantal hoorcolleges inzicht geboden in methoden van privaatrechtelijk onderzoek en in de verhouding tussen privaatrechtelijk onderzoek en andere wetenschapsdisciplines. De tijdens de colleges aangeboden theorie wordt tegelijkertijd bij het scriptieonderzoek in de praktijk gebracht.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Dit vak heeft tot doel inzicht te bieden in en (verdere) vaardigheden op te doen met methoden van privaatrechtelijk juridisch onderzoek. Het vak beoogt daarmee ondersteuning te bieden aan het scriptietraject dat in hetzelfde blok plaatsvindt.</body>

<body>

column3: Er worden in de maanden februari tot en met juni 10 seminars aangeboden voor de masterstudenten Beleid en Politiek, AOM, GMCS en Publiek Management.

column5: Theorie gebruik en onderzoeksopzet
Operationaliseren
Vragenlijstonderzoek
Participerende observatie
Evaluatieonderzoek
Interviewen
Kwalitatieve analyse
SPSS basis
SPSS geavanceerd
Formuleren van aanbevelingen

column3: Studenten zijn verplicht de seminars theorie/onderzoeksopzet en operationalisering te volgen. Daarnaast dienen zij tenminste twee aanvullende seminars te doen. Zij schrijven zich van te voren voor de seminars naar keuze in. De seminars zijn altijd op vrijdag.

De seminars bestaan deels uit het overdragen van kennis over de specifieke methodologische thematiek van dat seminar, en een gedeelte is gericht op het oefenen en ontwikkelen van de bijbehorende vaardigheden.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Door middel van deze seminars nemen de studenten de noodzakelijke kennis tot zich over de methodische aanpak van hun scriptieonderzoek. Door met deze kennis in de seminars concreet te oefenen ontwikkelen ze de bijbehorende vaardigheden om dit onderzoek daadwerkelijk goed uit te kunnen voeren. Doordat de seminars parallel worden aangeboden aan het stage-/scriptietraject kunnen studenten de aangeboden kennis en inzichten direct toepassen in hun scriptieonderzoek. </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89561,2019,Methodology of Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. CJ Clarke'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The course will introduce students to key concepts and arguments surrounding:

A) Theoretical modelling: explanation, understanding, idealization and abstraction, causal tendencies, modal hypotheses, the distinction between the practice of theoretical model building and applied models.

B) Causal inference: the Causal Markov assumption, exogeneity, heterogeneity, choosing an appropriate set of control variables, background causal knowledge, Bayesian methods, and hypothetico-deductive approaches in economics, especially Friedman’s instrumentalism.
C) Econometrics: the Lucas critique / microfoundations debates, structural models, the assumptions of regression analyses, representative agent models, methodological individualism.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: By the end of this course, students can:

1) Clarify the aims of idealized modelling in economics, and critically assess whether these models meet these aims, drawing on the debate between Cartwright, Alexandrova, Sugden, Reiss, Maki, Hausman and Till Grune Yanoff.
2) Evaluate the arguments for and against derivational robustness analysis as a method of empirical confirmation in economics.

3) Explain and distinguish the main obstacles to causal inference in economics, both for observational studies using regression analysis or instrumental variables techniques, or for social experiments.

4) Relate these general obstacles to causal inferences in economics to particular issues arising in econometrics, including the debate over microfoundations for macroeconomic models, influential critiques of macroeconomics by Leamer and Roemer.

column1: This course deepens the methodological expertise that students have gained in previous studies or preparatory trainings. While the course covers the basic features and applicability of various research methods, the emphasis is on students’ own usage of these methods, specifically at the design and data gathering stages of the research process. The course thus contributes to students’ ability to conduct research independently and strengths the skills needed in the research workshops and the MA thesis, which follow later in the program. Four types of research methods are covered: surveys, in-depth interviews, quantitative content analysis, and qualitative content analysis. The various methods are taught by different lecturers who bring their own research expertise to the modules.
Thematically, the course addresses a variety of topics, research subjects and media types.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Common research methods in the field of media and communication.

column1: Students have developed the skills to:

column2: • Evaluate research designs, measuring instruments, and sampling strategies (for the methods concerned).
• Understand key differences in how specific research methods are used and the kinds of data they convey.
• Develop their own research designs, measuring instruments, and sampling strategies in relation to concrete research questions about media production, content and usage.
• Gather valuable data through different research methods.
• Reflect on their use of different research methods.
• Work with peers in the discussion, development, and assessment of specific research strategies.

column1: This course focuses on qualitative research methods employed in the social sciences, particularly when studying phenomena in culture, media, and history. Whilst various qualitative research methods are contextualized and students are familiarized with their specific characteristics and uses in scientific research, the course is primarily a hands-on course. Students learn how to formulate fitting research questions, design research, and operationalize theoretical concepts. They gain practical experience in various methods of data collection and analysis. The primary focus of this course is on interviewing, but ample consideration will be given to ethnographic field research, narrative analysis, qualitative content analysis, and emerging methods within visual sociology.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>After completing the course, students have knowledge and understanding of the characteristics and applicability of a range of qualitative research methods. They will be able to apply particular methods such as participant observation and (semi) structured interviews, and will be able to argue for and against the use of qualitative data analysis methods like grounded theory and (critical) discourse analysis. Apart from a cognitive approach to qualitative research methods, students will learn how to design and execute a research project from proposal to report. The practical application of qualitative research methods is the focal point of this course.</body>
